text.wiki:
Turku ( TOOR-koo; Finnish: [ˈturku] (listen); Swedish: Åbo [ˈǒːbʊ] (listen), Finland Swedish: [ˈoːbu] (listen); in Russian: Турку, formerly Або) is a city on the southwest coast of Finland at the mouth of the Aura River, in the region of Finland Proper (Varsinais-Suomi). The region was originally called Suomi (Finland), which later became the name for the whole country.
It is unknown when Turku gained city rights. The Pope first mentioned the town Aboa in his Bulla in 1229 and the year is now used as the foundation year of the city.
As the oldest town in the country, Turku is the most important city in Finland, a status it retained for hundreds of years throughout the centuries under the rule of the Kingdom of Sweden. After the Finnish war, Finland became an autonomous grand duchy of the Russian Empire (1809) under the direct rule of the Czar and the capital of the autonomous Grand Duchy of Finland was moved to Helsinki (1812).
It was only after the last great fire in 1827 that most governmental institutions were moved to Helsinki along with the Academy of Turku (Turun Akatemia) founded in 1640, which then became the University of Helsinki.
Turku continued to be the most populous city in Finland until the end of the 1840s, and it remains the regional capital and an important business and cultural center and port.
Because of its long history, it has been the site of many important events, and has extensively influenced Finnish history. The history of the country is closely linked to Turku, the former capital.
Along with Tallinn, the capital city of Estonia, Turku was designated the European Capital of Culture for 2011. In 1996, it was declared the official Christmas City of Finland.Due to its location, Turku is a notable commercial and passenger seaport with over three million passengers traveling through the Port of Turku each year to Stockholm and Mariehamn.As of 30 September 2018, the population of Turku was 191,499 making it the sixth largest city in Finland. There were 330,192 inhabitants living in the Turku sub-region, ranking it as the third largest urban area in Finland after the Greater Helsinki area and Tampere sub-region. The city is officially bilingual as 5.2 percent of its population identify Swedish as a mother-tongue.


== Names and etymology ==

The Finnish name Turku originates from an Old East Slavic word, tǔrgǔ, meaning "market place". The word turku still means "market place" in some Finnish dialects.
The Swedish name Åbo may be a simple combination of å ("river; creek; large stream") and bo ("dwelling"). There is however an old legal term called "åborätt" (meaning roughly "right to live at"), which gave citizens (called "åbo") the inheritable right to live at land owned by the crown (å meant at or on in old Swedish, now på).In Finnish, the genitive of Turku is Turun, meaning "of Turku". The Finnish names of organizations and institutes of Turku often begin with this word, as in Turun yliopisto for the University of Turku.


== History ==
Turku has a long history as Finland's largest city and occasionally as the administrative center of the country, but for the last two hundred years has been surpassed by Helsinki. The city's identity stems from its status as the oldest city in Finland and the country's first capital. Originally, the word "Finland" referred only to the area around Turku (hence the title, "Finland Proper" for the region).

Although archaeological findings in the area date back to the Stone Age and early literary sources such as Al-Idrisi's world map from 1154 mentions Turku, the town of Turku was officially founded in late 13th century. Turku Cathedral was consecrated in 1300.During the Middle Ages, Turku was the seat of the Bishop of Turku (a title later upgraded to Archbishop of Turku), covering then the eastern half of the Kingdom of Sweden (most of the present-day Finland) until the 17th century. Even if Turku had no official capital status, both the short-lived institutions of Dukes and Governors-General of Finland usually had their Finnish residences there. In the aftermath of the War against Sigismund, the town was the site of the Åbo Bloodbath. In 1640, the first university in Finland, the Royal Academy of Turku, was founded in Turku. Turku was also the meeting place for the States of Finland in 1676.

After the Finnish War, which ended when Sweden ceded Finland to Imperial Russia at the Treaty of Fredrikshamn in 1809, Turku became briefly the official capital, but soon lost the status to Helsinki, as Emperor Alexander I felt that Turku was too far from Russia and too aligned with Sweden to serve as the capital of the Grand Duchy of Finland. The change officially took place in 1812. The government offices that remained in Turku were finally moved to the new capital after the Great Fire of Turku, which destroyed a large portion of the city in 1827. After the fire, a new and safer city plan was drawn up by German architect Carl Ludvig Engel, who had also designed the new capital, Helsinki. Turku remained the largest city in Finland for another twenty years.

In 1918, a new university, the Åbo Akademi – the only Swedish language university in Finland – was founded in Turku. Two years later, the Finnish language University of Turku was founded alongside it. These two universities are the second and third to be founded in Finland, both by private donations.
In the 20th century, Turku was called "Finland's gateway to the West" by historians such as Jarmo Virmavirta. The city enjoyed good connections with other Western European countries and cities, especially since the 1940s with Stockholm across the Gulf of Bothnia. In the 1960s, Turku became the first Western city to sign a twinning agreement with Leningrad in the Soviet Union, leading to greater inter-cultural exchange and providing a new meaning to the city's 'gateway' function. After the fall of Communism in Russia, many prominent Soviets came to Turku to study Western business practices, among them Vladimir Putin, then Leningrad's deputy mayor.As for architecture in the city, both the body of architectural styles as well as the prevalent way of living have experienced significant changes in the 20th century. While having survived relatively intact throughout the years of war 1939–1945, the city faced increasing changes in the 1950s and 1960s due to rising demands for apartments, the eagerness to rebuild, and most of all the new development of infrastructure (especially increased automobile traffic). The wooden one- to two-story houses that were the dominant mode of building in the city were mostly demolished in the 1950s and 1960s to both enable more efficient building and to ease vehicle traffic. This resulted in the destruction of buildings that were, in later decades, seen as beautiful and worth saving. Some individual buildings remain controversial to this day when it comes to their demolition in the decades after the war. For example, the building of Hotel Phoenix that stood on corner of the Market Square was torn down to make way for a large, multistory apartment building in 1959. The building was significant both for its location and history: having stood on one of the most valuable lots in the city center since 1878, the building had, for example, served as the first main building of the University of Turku. Other buildings whose demolition was seen as scandalous, either already at the time of action or proved to be so in later years, include The Nobel House (subject to the very first photograph ever taken in Finland) and the building of Old Hotel Börs which was built in jugendstil in 1909 by Frithiof Strandell.


== Geography ==

Located at the mouth of the Aura river in the southwestern corner of Finland, Turku covers an area of 245 square kilometres (95 sq mi) of land, spread over both banks of the river. The eastern side, where the Turku Cathedral is located, is popularly referred to as täl pual jokke ("this side of the river"), while the western side is referred to as tois pual jokke ("the other side of the river"). The city center is located close to the river mouth, on both sides of the river, though development has recently been expanding westward.There are ten bridges over the Aura river in Turku. The oldest of the current bridges is Auransilta, which was constructed in 1904. The newest bridge is Kirjastosilta ('library bridge'), a pedestrian-only bridge built in 2013. The Föri, a small ferry that transports pedestrians and bicycles across the river without payment, is a well known feature of the city.
With a population of approximately 300,000, the Turku Region (LAU 1) is the third largest urban region in Finland, after Greater Helsinki and the area around Tampere. The region includes, in addition to the city itself the following municipalities: Askainen, Kaarina, Lemu, Lieto, Masku, Merimasku, Mynämäki, Naantali, Nousiainen, Paimio, Piikkiö, Raisio, Rusko, Rymättylä, Sauvo, Vahto, and Velkua.
A more exclusive definition for the urban area is the city region of Turku with a population around 235,000 consisting of four major municipalities Kaarina, Raisio, Naantali, and Turku.


=== Administrative subdivisions ===

The city is divided into 78 districts and nine wards that do not function as local government units. There are, however, some projects that are based on the district divisions, particularly in the eastern part of the city, where unemployment is high in certain areas. The largest populated districts are Varissuo and Runosmäki. By area, however, Kakskerta and Paattinen, formed from former municipalities that were annexed to the city proper in the mid-20th century, constitute the largest districts.As many of the small neighbouring municipalities from the north and south of the city were annexed during the mid-20th century, Turku is today shaped like an elongated pear. The city centre and most of the suburban areas lie in the middle, separated from the less densely populated northern rural areas by the Turku bypass, that forms part of European route E18. Islands such as Ruissalo, Hirvensalo and Kakskerta, forming the southern part of the city, are also sparsely populated and mostly contain summer residences, with the exception of some districts in Hirvensalo which are currently growing into upper-middle-class suburbs.


=== Climate ===

Situated by the Baltic Sea and sheltered by the islands of the Archipelago Sea, Turku has a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfb). Like much of southern Finland, the city experiences warm summers, with temperatures ranging up to 30 °C (86 °F), and relatively cold winters with frequent snowfall. The warmest month of the year is July, with an average temperature of 17.5 °C (64 °F), whereas the coldest month is February. The average year-round temperature is 5.5 °C (42 °F). Winter usually starts in early December, and spring in late March.
Precipitation in Turku averages 720 mm (28.3 in) a year. The rainiest month of the year is August, when the city receives on average 80 mm (3.1 in) of rainfall. In April, the driest month of the year, the figure is only 32 mm (1.3 in). The average air pressure at sea level is 101.2 kilopascals (29.9 inHg), with little variance throughout the year.
Operational since 1955, the city's weather station is located at an altitude of 47 metres (154 feet) at Turku Airport.


== Demographics ==

At the end of 2004, the Turku region (including the economic districts of Turku and Åboland) had a population of 319,632, out of which 174,824 people lived in the city of Turku. The city's population density is 718 inhabitants per square kilometre.83.1% of Turku's population speak Finnish as their native language, while 5.4% speak Swedish. The next most widely spoken languages are Russian (1.6%), Arabic (1.4%), Kurdish (1%), Albanian (0.8%), Estonian (0.8%) and Somali (0.8%). 93.3% of the population are Finnish citizens, and the most sizeable minorities are from Russia, Estonia, Iraq, Iran, Albania, Sweden, Somalia, China, and Denmark. Like all other Finnish cities, Turku does not collect information about the ethnic and religious makeup of its population.


== Economy ==

The business district in the city's economy is centred on the Port of Turku and other service-oriented industries. The city is also a renowned high tech centre – the Turku Science Park area in Kupittaa hosts over 300 companies from the fields of biotechnology and information technology, as well as several institutions of higher learning that work in closely with the business sector. This cooperative element is seen as a particularly important factor with regards to the city's expected future economic development, as outlined in the Turku Strategy that is published annually by the city council.
At least the following major Finnish companies have their corporate headquarters in Turku: HKScan and Hesburger. Other major companies which have operations in Turku include Bayer, Fläkt Woods, Meyer Werft, Orion Corporation and Wärtsilä.
As of June 2015, over 280,000 people were registered as being without employment in Finland. This put June's numbers at 10.0 percent of the population, 0.8 percentage points higher than June 2014. Men's unemployment rate was 10.5 percent and women's 9.4 percent.


== Culture ==

Cultural venues in Turku include several theatres, cinemas, and art galleries, and a city philharmonic orchestra. The city's cultural centre organises a number of regular events, most notably the Medieval Market in July each year. Turku is also the official Christmas city of Finland, and 'Christmas Peace' in Finland is declared on every 24 December from the Brinkkala Hall balcony. The Turku music festival and the rock festival Ruisrock (held on the island of Ruissalo) are among the oldest of its kind in Scandinavia. The city also hosts another rock festival, Down by the Laituri, and one of the largest electronic music festivals in Northern Europe, UMF (Uuden Musiikin Festivaali, "New Music Festival"), in addition to a vibrant nightlife, centred on the Market Square.
There are also numerous museums, such as the Turku Art Museum and the Wäinö Aaltonen Museum of Art. The Åbo Akademi University maintains the Sibelius Museum, which is the only museum in Finland specialising in the field of music. Apart from these, there are also several historical museums that display the city's medieval period, such as the Turku Castle, which has been a functional historical museum since 1881, and the Aboa Vetus museum, built in the late 1990s over the 14th century archaeological site. The Luostarinmäki handicrafts museum, converted from residential buildings that survived the Great Fire of Turku in 1827, was the first Scandinavian venue to receive the "Golden Apple" tourism award.
Considered to be the most important religious building in Finland, the Turku Cathedral has borne witness to many important events in the nation's history and has become one of the city's most recognizable symbols with the Turku Castle. The cathedral is situated in the heart of Turku next to the Old Great Square, by the Aura River. Its presence extends beyond the local precinct by having the sound of its bells chiming at noon broadcast on national radio. It is also central to Finland's annual Christmas celebrations. It is also known as resting place for many remarkable bishops and captains of war as well as one Queen of Sweden, Catherine Månsdotter.Turku is European Capital of Culture in 2011, and the city council has approved numerous projects to boost the city's image in preparation for that status.
The Declaration of Christmas Peace has been a tradition in Finland from the Middle Ages every year, except in 1939 due to the Winter War. The declaration takes place on the Old Great Square of Turku, Finland's official 'Christmas City', at noon on Christmas Eve. The declaration ceremony begins with the hymn Jumala ompi linnamme (Martin Luther's Ein feste Burg ist unser Gott) and continues with the Declaration of Christmas Peace read from a parchment roll in Finnish and Swedish.


== Sports ==

The city has two football teams playing at the top national level, the Veikkausliiga: FC Inter and TPS. TPS is one of the oldest football clubs in Finland. Both teams play their home matches at Veritas Stadion in the district of Kupittaa.
HC TPS of Turku is one of the most successful teams in Finnish ice hockey history. It plays in the Finnish top league, SM-liiga. HC TPS has won the national championship 11 times, the latest being from season 2009–2010. Gatorade Center, formerly named HK Arena, located in the Artukainen district, is used as the venue for HC TPS games.
The Paavo Nurmi Marathon is an annual sporting event in Turku, named after the world-famous runner Paavo Nurmi, who was born and raised in the city.
Finland's most successful tennis player, Jarkko Nieminen, was born and lives in the neighbouring county of Masku
Turku Titans is a lacrosse club based in Turku with a relevantly successful history with three silver medals and one gold medal in the national lacrosse league in Finland. The Titans women's team has also had a successful history. The FIL U19 2012 World Lacrosse Championships were also held in the city.


== Government and politics ==

Being both a regional and provincial capital, Turku is an important administrative centre, hosting the seat of the Archbishop of Finland and a Court of Appeal. Aleksi Randell has been the mayor of Turku since 2010.
The city council of Turku has 67 seats. Following the 2017 municipal election, the council seats are allocated in the following way: National Coalition Party 17 seats, Green League 14, Social Democrats 12, Left Alliance 12, True Finns 5, Centre Party 3, Swedish People's Party 3 and Christian Democrats 1. The current chair of the city board is Minna Arve from National Coalition Party.
Results of the 2011 Finnish parliamentary election in Turku:

National Coalition Party   23.7%
Social Democratic Party   19.4%
True Finns   15.8%
Left Alliance   12.7%
Green League   11.4%
Swedish People's Party   5.8%
Centre Party   4.7%
Christian Democrats   3.1%


== Transport ==

For a city of its size, Turku has a moderate public transport network of bus routes, which is comparable to the bus network of similar-sized Tampere. The bus network is managed and supervised by the Turku City Region’s Public Transport Committee (FÖLI) (Finnish: Turun kaupunkiseudun joukkoliikennelautakunta, Swedish: kollektivtrafiknämnden för Åbo stadsregion), and is operated mainly by private companies. Bus traffic to and in the neighbouring municipalities of Kaarina, Lieto, Naantali, Raisio and Rusko are also handled by FÖLI. The bus rates are the same when traveling within these municipalities.Rail traffic to and from Turku is handled by the Finnish national carrier, VR. The number of services has fallen and only the railways towards Tampere and Helsinki are now in use. The railway stations currently used for passenger traffic are the Turku Central railway station in Pohjola, and two smaller stations in Kupittaa and the Port of Turku.
There is no local rail traffic at the moment, as the city's popular tram services were discontinued in 1972, and the various local railway lines to neighbouring towns and municipalities were all abolished during the late 20th century. However, there are plans for a light rail system in the Turku region in the near future. This system would more ably serve major suburbs of the city such as Varissuo and Runosmäki, as well as the neighbouring cities.The State of Finland has announced plans to support Espoo with 30% of full expenses on a new metro rail, the Regional Council of Southwest Finland is going to use this as a test case for a new light rail network in Turku.The Turku Bus Station and the Turku Central railway station are currently located in different places. The City of Turku is planning to combine these two in a new greater station complex in the near future. This new travel center will consist of a hotel and several shopping estates. This center will connect all public transportation from commuter trains to long-distance buses.
Turku's most significant highways for traffic are Highway 1 leading to Helsinki; Highway 10 leading to Hämeenlinna; Highway 9 leading to Tampere, Jyväskylä, Kuopio and Joensuu; Highway 8 leading to Pori, Vaasa and Oulu; and the Turku Ring Road, which protrudes circumferentially from Turku.
Turku Airport is located 8 kilometres (5 miles) to the north of the city centre, partly in the neighbouring municipality of Rusko. The airport is served by six passenger airlines, including airBaltic and SAS Scandinavian, and one cargo airline.
There are also daily ferry services from the Port of Turku to Sweden and the Åland Islands, operated by Silja Line and Viking Line. These are something of a Finnish cultural tradition (see ruotsinlaiva), and people often travel long distances across Finland to Turku just to take a cruise across the Gulf of Bothnia.
The Archipelago Sea boat traffic is handled by, among others, SS Ukkopekka, an old steamship that cruises on the route Turku-Naantali-Turku.
Turku is the only city in Finland to have three long-distance railway stations: Turku Central, Port of Turku, and Kupittaa.


== Education ==

Turku has a longer educational history than any other Finnish city – the first school in the city, the Cathedral School, was founded along with Turku Cathedral in the late 13th century. The first university in Finland, the "Royal Academy of Turku" (now University of Helsinki), was established in the city in 1640. In 1820, the first school in Finland conforming to the Bell-Lancaster method was founded in Turku with the aim of making primary education more inclusive to the lower classes.
Turku is home to about 35,000 higher education students. There are two universities and several "polytechnics" in the town.
The Finnish University of Turku is the second largest university in Finland (18,000 students), as measured by student enrollment, and one of the oldest as well, having been founded in 1920. Åbo Akademi, founded 1918 as the second university of Finland, is Finland's only Swedish-language university. Turku School of Economics merged with The University of Turku in 2010, and Åbo handelshögskola, its Swedish counterpart, with Åbo Akademi 1980. The central hospital of Turku, Turku University Hospital, is affiliated with the University and it is used as a teaching hospital.
Turku University of Applied Sciences is the second largest polytechnic in Finland after Metropolia University of Applied Sciences. Also Novia University of Applied Sciences and Diaconia University of Applied Sciences have campuses in the town.
Turku is one of only two cities in Finland to have an established international school (the other city being Helsinki). Turku International School, located in the eastern district of Varissuo, has been operating since 2003. By an agreement signed between the city of Turku and the University of Turku, Turun normaalikoulu takes care of the teaching in the international school.


== Media ==

The most widely read newspaper of Turku, and the area around it, is the daily regional morning newspaper Turun Sanomat, with a readership of over 70% of the population every day. Åbo Underrättelser, a Swedish language newspaper published in Turku, is the oldest newspaper in Finland, having been published since 1824. The free-of-charge Turkulainen newspaper is also among the most popular newspapers, together with the local edition of Metro International and the national evening tabloid Ilta-Sanomat. There are also a number of local newspapers such as Kulmakunta (for the eastern suburbs of Turku, including Varissuo and Lauste), and Rannikkoseutu (for the area around the neighbouring cities of Raisio and Naantali).
The first Finnish newspaper Tidningar Utgifne Af et Sällskap i Åbo, in Swedish, was started in Turku in 1771, as well as the first Finnish-language newspaper Suomenkieliset Tieto-Sanomat which was started in 1775.
The newspaper Turun Sanomat also operates a regional television station, called Turku TV. The Finnish national broadcaster Yleisradio screens local news, daily from Monday to Friday, for the Southwest Finland (including the regions of Southwest Finland and Satakunta) residents. All Finnish national TV channels are viewable and national radio channels audible in the Turku area. In addition, a number of local radio stations, e.g. Auran Aallot, Radio Sata and Radio Robin Hood are operational. Local public service radio stations are Yle Turun Radio in Finnish language (the regional version of Yle Radio Suomi) and Yle Vega Åboland in Swedish language (the regional version of Yle Vega).

Jiri “Linkzr” Masalin, Professional Overwatch player for the team Houston Outlaws and two time player for Finland in the Overwatch World Cup

text.quote: Iconic Lutheran church, restored after an 1827 fire, with frescoes, royal tombs & religious museum.
trip: We needed an easy place to visit near the city centre and this church is just few hundred meters from the centre. There was a nice park next to the church also. The church itself is beautiful both inside and outside. Inside there is a lot to see.
Beautiful church close to the centre of Turku. Great exterior and interior architecture in addition to free entrance makes it a must see spot in town!
It looks nice from the outside and is a highlight of the city landscape. However, the cathedral is pretty mediocre inside.

The cathedral in Turku is very old, and very beautiful. There are many crypts with each there own history, and if you are lucky musicians will be practicing for the next church concert, while you walk around.
Open every Day. Beautiful, and a very peaceful experience. Free entry. There is a small museum inside we didnt explore (payable)
The church is large, and magnificent from outside. In the inside it has though not very much decoration.
Monstrous building, in protestant style, almost empty but masses are still celebrate. Some interesting crypts. Recommend to visit this place.

it's one of most important places of Turku. It's located near Aura river in a nice district of Turku. It's possible walk around without any car noise. Considered to be the most important religious building in Finland, during Christmas time you can enjoy some nice Christmas

This cathedral is similar to many in Europe, with some notable differences. What I especially liked about this one is that each station has a QR reader with information available in English. Quite fascinating!!
A very nice and cooling place to be at and also the locals here are really helpful in directions. A very worth to go place
A landmark of Turkey and a must visit. The cathedral dominates the skyline of Turkey. It is within easy walking distance of downtown.

A very nice building located in the middle of what I consider a park, it's something you should visit if you are in the city. I can't speak of it's interiors, because unfortunately I visited on times it was closed, but the building itself, specially at night when the lights are

The Turku Cathedral is arguably one of the most important historical buildings in the country, having originally been raised as a wooden building in the 13th century and build and rebuilt several times after that. The great fire of Turku saw it burn and the current walls still
On a sunny day, the cathedral looks so good, the inside is marvelous and it is just stunning in general.
Worth a quick visit for some, others will linger. The nature of the structural works are interesting.
Very interesting place to visit. 700 years history. Unique spirit. High historical and also present significance.

The principle Lutheran Cathedral of Finland was started building in 1258. Then rebuilt and completed many times. Now it's a masterpiece! While coming up steep stairs you start feeling the meeting with Wonder! The Cathedral is very high and beautiful especially at nights. Every

A lovely church to visit. It's free and only 1 euro for retirees to visit the museum which has beautiful silverware, textiles, wooden statues, etc. It's in nice grounds with seats and surrounded by trees and a statue of Per Brahe. Located near the river and a shirt walk to city

Visited Turku on a day visit from Helsinki to meet my wife's Finnish relatives, whom she had never met. We had some time,and gotten off at the wrong train stop, we meandered into town. We were only going to the Cathedral if we had time. Situated along the banks of the river

We were staying on the S/S Bore and walked to the Turku Cathedral to attend the Anglican service at 16:00 (a long but pleasant walk). Along the way, there were lots of interesting boats, turned into bars and restaurants. The service was in English and though. a very small

I found the cathedral not that interesting, and packed with yelling children. On the other end, the museum was very good (and quiet). Take your time there, open the drawers to admire the clothes. A very stirring wooden statue of Jesus in his casket.

Beautiful old age church... Wide steps at the entrance Inside, a big big organ, it was playing when we entered, it made the atmosphere more magical Quiet surroundings, Church is near river Aura. We walked to the church from Turku railway station, Don't miss if you are in Turku.
Very nice inside and do not miss it if you are in Turku. Besides if you need an urgent toilet there is one clean inside the curch.

You cannot miss it if you are in Turku. You can see it miles away. It is free admission for starters. And quiet, cool place to sit and marvel at the vaulted ceiling and side chapels. The reformation stripped the cathedral of the wall illustrations but the whitewashed interior

Very very beautiful and tranquil. This cathedral is filled with interesting items and has exquisite accoustics if you are lucky enough to go on a day when an opera singer and pianist were practicing (as we did).

Nice building inside but no atmosphere. We walked around inside and I didn't get that cathedral feeling. We sat in it for 15 minutes or so, to feel the essence of the building. I think you might have to be Finnish to understand it. I left feeling somewhat anticlimactic and

The seven hundred years old cathedral is the main Lutheran church in Finland and has regular services through out the week. The solemn stone architecture to which additions and alterations have been made over the centuries is impressing, much of the interior was destroyed in the
Free of charge and a nice cafe just outside the doors. Not as decorative but has some nice features such as the side chapels
We visited during the Midevail Festival, with live music being played out front next to the new cafe. The church was filled with artifacts and signs explaining the history.

Inside the cathedral is the Turku Cathedral museum that gives a hindsight to life in medieval Turku and the different phases in the history of the church and its surroundings. A must if you're interested in Finnish history and relics.
The cathedral is in the style of Gothic cathedrals, imposing and large. Inside there are many chapels, sculptures and special paintings. The organ is beautiful.
From outside the cathedral is quite impresive. Unfortunately, there was a service and we could not visit the inside.
Enjoyable to visit, not a lot of instruction sin English, once the rehearsal started the cathedral came to life

Visiting this mighty church that has stood through the centuries, is really worth while! It gives the visitor a sence of the awe it awoke and authority it had (and to some extent still had) over people in earlier times. For concerts the acoustic is really beautiful. Upstairs the

While exploring near the river,we could see the tower in the distance and once we got closer, we realized it was the Cathedral. It sits on a bit of a rise and as you walk up you see the amazing stonework as well as the wooden door of a cathedral that has been there for about 800

The Turku Cathedral stands on the shore of Aura river and represents an interesting place to visit. Turku became the most important trading centre in Finland in 1300 so bishops See was transferred there. There are dignitaries buried in the church from powerful families and

A lovely peaceful place to visit. There is not much of the adornment typical of large European cathedrals perhaps because it is an ecumenical space and with a Lutheran heritage. There is no explanation in English that we could find. A friendly female minister invited us to

This is a must-see while in Turku because of its beautiful architecture and history. While the church is free to enter, there is a modest 2 euro fee to enter the museum. The museum is small yet interesting, and it also gives a different view down into the cathedral.
Just a place to call down and to relax in. a place to relax and enjoy the awesome church. One of my favourites.

It is a true medieval building witnessing many bad and good events in the last 700 years. Just sit down and relax, when you are ready walk around and read the guidance (through phone). Not a common experience in Scandinavia.
U can't miss that place while visiting Turku. Big, beautiful, monumental, quiet. Upstairs you can find small museum (2 eur for ticket).

This Gothic Cathedral was completed in 1300. It is situated next to the Old Great Square, by the river Aura. It is a must-see church in Finland, as it is regarded as Finland's most valuable historical building. The entrance to the Cathedral is free but you have pay 2 euros for

We were pleased to be able to wander through this lovely town and see some of the sites one of which is this lovely old cathedral. It is apparently a national shrine and is the main church of the evangelical lutheran church of Finland. Compared to other churches in Europe it is
One of the oldest churches in Finland. If you are interested in architecture this place should be in your Turku trip list.

Just like the Turku castle, also Turku Cathedral is the symbol of the city. The church is hundreds years old but in very good condition. The church stands in the center on the other side of the river from the market square and the modern center of the city. If you only have a

Massive in every way, this is one end of the city. An absolute must do when in Turku. If you are visiting the Turku Palace, walk by the river to the other end of the city to witness the grandeur of this cathedral. The lady at the entrance was the nicest person we met in the

Turku Cathedral has been – and it still is – the national cathedral for Finland. You can feel the medieval feeling, see the only royal tomb in Finland (Karin Månsdotter, queen of Sweden), take a candle and sit down peacefully. I try to visit it every time when I have some time
Really impressive.. especially the knights graves were really cool and tell Turku's rich history....
Lovely church quite modern inside . Lovely stain glass windows however plain but very historical . Lovely spire and garden area around the cathedral . Worth a visit

The Åbo/Turku domkyrka is the national shrine of Finland and the archbishop resides here. Built in the 13th century and rebuilt and restored several times (recently in the 1970-ies). Well worth seeing. For a small fee you can visit a museum part located on top of the south

This , along with most of the city , burned down and so the original church was rebuilt and is now used for weddings in the summer every 30 minutes. Name for the priest that forced people to be baptized was killed by a local farmer.

This is definitely the biggest church, but is a beautiful, peace, calm and very nice place. There are many interesting inside and if you find a audio-guide is super because there are many things to look. You will walk over tombs and the church has "secret" places. The entry is
Entry is free. This is a huge cathedral. It is a lovely and light, airy space. Peaceful. Very significant in national history

I visited the Turku Cathedral during a transit stop at the city. I walked around and came across the cathedral. It was a beautiful cathedral and worth a quick visit of an hour or less. There are other buildings and shops nearby.

It basically reminds me of a famous saying "Peace is just not in absence of war, but as a cathedral, peace should be constructed with patience and unshakable faith" and Turku cathedral is just this way. All the paintings of almighty enumerating his greatness and alluring wall
Impressive and large cathedral, but nothing memorable within the place. Some stain glass windows, but little else.

I walked here along the river as recommended by the travel guide I read. There was a dance festival going on during my visit, so I didn’t go inside. But I walked around the outside which was interesting.

I’m a Church and Cathedral person and I loved Turku’s Cathedral. It’s not as lavish as some that we have seen but is still beautiful in its own right. It has history which you can find out about in the visit to the museum. Worth a visit.

Very impressive and also holds a small museum. Definitely worth a visit if churches and cathedrals are of personal interest. At times there’s also a cafe that directs the proceedings to mission welfare. You can sit on the stairs of the cathedral and enjoy a nice cup of coffee
It's not really much to see and I'm even from Finland. Surely it's old but that's about it. It's not pretty and it's certainly nothing to travel for. Just kinda one of those been-there-done-that.
Visited the church today. The inside is very nice. You must check out the side rooms, they are very interesting.

This cathedral has a great deal of history on display. It’s very well preserved and easy to access. It’s just the other side of the river from the city centre and well worth he short, beautiful walk. Take your time to see all the cathedral has to offer.

Beautiful inside and out. Very peaceful. Take time out to just sit and pray or just be still before moving on. We visited on a beautiful but busy day outside and this was a time to reflect for a while.

Visited at end of March when it was pretty cold outside. 1st time I've ended up feeling warmer inside a cathedral. If you care nothing about religion it can still be a nice place to warm up and think about life.
The only place in Turku worth seeing. The lady at the reception was very helpful. She even guided us to some nice and reasonable places for food. A good experience overall.

The museum upstairs has a nice collection of historical church art, statues, altar clothes and dishes. Remember to open the "secret drawers" in the back as many of the most beautiful clothes can be found there. There are rarely other people in there and the lights have movement
Very beautiful building from the outside especially. A great place to see the New Year's fireworks !
Great place to visit if you have 30mins to spare. Amazing architecture internally and can spend very long time staring at the ceiling and the paintings on the wall.

Even if you are not religious person Turku Cathedral is a place you want to see. It is approximately 800 years old, though original structures have not survived to this day. Due several wars and fires the church has been renovated several times and today it is one of the finest

Turku Cathedral is one of the most beautiful churches in Turku. There is numberious interesting stopping points, witch contains historical information. You can scan quark codes, and read information about historical persons, happening and architecture. In Christmas time, there

Loved walking around this fully functioning church. You have to pay to go upstairs to enjoy the museum part of the church, but there's plenty to see in the main sanctuary area. As many informed us, this is the "most important church in Finland" and has a fascinating history to

Not to be missed, the Cathedral and Museum are an amazing record of the history of Turku. The many artifacts in the museum tell of the history of both the building and its rebuild after the Great Fire of Turku in 1827. English language brochures were available for the cathedral

Wooden Turku Cathedral was built in the 13th century. It burned during the great fire of Turku and was rebuilt in 1827. The church is the religious home fore the evangelical Lutheran church in Finland. The church is historical and has a special place in annual Finnish Christmas

The change from Catholicism to Lutheranism is very evident in the austere decorations of the cathedral. The building is interesting, a mix and match on the outside and very nice on the inside with high vaults. The park and trees surrounding are also nice.

Me and my husband were here a sunny and warm day in June 2017. We have visited many cathedrals all over Europe and thought this was one of the most beautiful. Just plain gorgeous! If you have a physical handicap the way in have some very high and steep stairs, but inside it's

There is nothing special about this building. No particularly nice park around it. Museum costs 2 eur for adults. Bach on programme at the moment, till October (when talking about music).Simply pass by when you are around and see how it looks inside. Or dont. Doesnt really

Beautiful cathedral and amazing building. Many little details to notice on the walls, floors, etc. Only thing that they should fix is that they only have QR codes for you to scan with the phone, but nothing written for the tourists. If you want to figure out what you are looking

This big and messy-looking brick pile looks impressive but shaggy from the outside. Inside, things are neater-looking but equally impressive. As in most churches in Finland, the prayer books are stacked and available for reading on the honor system.

This kind of churches are quite rare in Finland. There is pretty much to see compared to many other churches, especially if you visit also the small museum upstairs. It's not too expensive, 2 euros for adult and 1 euro for kids, students and senior citizen.

Underestimated by locals, this 13th century cathedral embodies the history of Turku and Finland in many aspects. The guided tours are excellent and very tourist-friendly. The cathedral grounds also hold many monuments that are at the core of Finnish (and Swedish) history.
Wonderfully peaceful, yet majestic building with plenty to see. Located on a beautiful place next to the river. Easy to walk to from the city center.

Having visited many of the major cathedrals in Italy and France, it is nice to be in cathedral that is relatively unadorned and modest. This is a huge cathedral with an imposing spire, a grand entrance, vaulted ceilings and enormous columns, an incredible organ and beautiful
Interesting to see it's not very decorated from inside. We visited just when there was some concert rehearsal and enjoyed just sitting and listening.

A large imposing building approached across a large open plaza. Fairly plain on the outside, built from brick and stone. Inside fairly plain as well. Tall brick pillars from huge arches down each side of the main space leading the eye forward to the altar. Several side chapels.
When entering the Cathedral, try to find the very old bricks outside the building, where there are very old marks of the brick makers. Figures of keys are the best ones!
Was impressed by the size of this cathedral, great being there when the bells are rung.Some interesting artifacts from medieval times
We attended a service here. Excellent acoustics. Large and imposing space with several beautiful stained glass windows and huge art works.

The Cathedral is on the opposite side of the river from the modern town centre so you cross one of the many bridges. It is a short walk. It stands on a small hill and is an unusual mixture of stone and brick. Inside there are old private chapels of historic nobility linked to

I visited this Cathedral with a group of friends.There is a cafe located at the base of the actual building. It was very cosy & inexpensive but added to the atmosphere for our visit. (check opening times before visit).We walked around the outside first & had a knowledgeable

Turun tuomiokirkko, the Turku cathedral is one of the most important buildings in Finland with a huge role in history. The building is medieval and very interesting, packed with history. Entrance is free and you can get a free guide to your smartphone. Currently there is a

The cathedral is beautiful and free to enter. I liked the children's exhibit of the 500th anniversary of the Reformation. In addition there is a Cathedral Museum which displays some of the cathedral's treasures and has a small admission charge.
Worth seeing this for sure! It has incredible history and is so beautiful to see how it has been restored. Definitely a must see while in Turku.
The Cathedral still in use and seem to be up to date with the needs of a modern Cathedral. A small museum inside the cathedral is worth a visit. The Ejby chalk is here to be seen.

Turku Cathedral is like no other Lutheran Church we have seen in Finland (7 or so now). It reminds me more of the Catholic or Church of England Cathedrals with the open vaulted ceilings, tall columns and chapels or graves in the alcoves. The church is still Lutheran in adornment
I entered this church and it was a big beautiful church from the inside. Luckily I got to hear the organ being played. It created a beautiful ambience.

This church is located by the river Aura in the city center, the entrance is free which is great! Amazing interior, with many benches where you can sit and enjoy the atmosphere and feel the history of past times.
The Cathedral was built in 1229 and is the oldest Cathedral of Finland. Very nice building with beautiful interior. Certainly worth a visit.

Turku Cathedral has a very interesting history. It began as a catholic church, made of wood in the 13th century, and now, constructed of stone, is the mother church of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland. The cathedral's south gallery includes a very interesting museum of
A nice medieval cathedral in Finland's former capital, located near the city centre. Interior is also quite impressive. Entrance is free.

This church is quite old and a relic in a lot of ways but it has seen so much time pass by and it has seen so much history being created all around. This feeling gave me a sense of nostalgia as I entered it. Despite being so old it is well preserved. When I visited a ceremony

Turku's cathedral is outstanding. Despite the many changes throughout the time, we can still consider this church as a piece of the Middle Ages (XIII). It is a crucial place for the history of Finland. It features a museum and a cafe.

Very well worth visiting, in an interesting historic part of Turku, it has charm as well as grandeur. I was slightly disconcerted to realise that not only was I initially entering the building just as a wedding was starting, I was actually holding open the cathedral door to
The oldest church of Finland from the 13th century, the old Finnish-Swedish noble tombs and nice cafe in the cellar

If you want to get a sense of medieval Finland, come to Turqu instead of Helsinki. Not only is Turqu older, it has two stunning monuments from the Middle Ages: Turqu Castle and the Turqu Cathedral. This cathedral must have looked like a skyscraper to the early Finns, because it

We arrived for a second time (to cover the small admission fee). As other reviewers have said, it's big, when compared to (say) Porvoo cathedral (qv). Unexpectedly I was touched by the phenomenological experience of hearing a striking organ recital (see photo). We visited Turku

Almost the oldest church in Finland and gives also a historical view from 15th century what has happened in Finland. They have very good qr codes to read more information about graves which are under the church and history over all.

The cathedral is old and beautiful and very big - it is higher than anything in the surroundings and seems therefore very majestic. Inside there are many old things and tombs and you can really feel the history. It is of course a Lutheran church so there is not so much gold and
This church is just so beautiful. And perfect for amazing concerts. There is some magic when you listen beautiful choirs singing.

Turku cathedral is in the heart of the city, and actually the see of the archbishop of all of Finland. It dates back to the Middle Ages, and there's a small museum upstairs (fee) where vestments and chalices over the ages are on display. The style of the cathedral interior is

With only one day to visit Turku, seeing this medieval cathedral was at the top of our list. It's so beautiful and peaceful inside and it's also very welcoming. They have displays to help visitors understand the history. Allow time to thoroughly explore and appreciate the

The cathedral is a spectacular sight on a sunny day. IT looms tall over the city, as it has done for centuries. the stairs to the door are steep, and the door is very large - all part of the creation of a lasting impression of power and authority. Inside it is very plain -
a century old church with a museum and tons and tons of interesting artifacts which can be viewed with a small amount of entrance fee

The place is a must visit in Turku. The church in a way symbolizes the city. It can be seen in a lot of post cards and every person who visited and lived in the city has a picture of it or have it as a back ground in their pictures. It always provides a good backdrop in all

During a casual walk along the river after we checked in to the hotel we saw the cathedral. Decided to stop in and check it out. Wow! There are a service going on and the singing was beautiful. The place is an awesome sight and something worth visiting.Glad we stopped and check

Do not miss this. Inside lies a Queen and she is not Finnish but Swedish. The pipe organ was playing, there are tombs and altars, there are old paintings on the walls faded with time, there are bodies buried beneath the church. This is such a fascinating place, a historical and
The cathedral is really beautiful (not as much in the inside than the outside). It's good to visit it to understand the history of Turku.

Every time I visit Turku I always pop into the cathedral. Regardless of how many times I see it, it'll always be a treat on the eye and leave me smiling. The outside doesn't really represent what you'd see inside. Both are still visually beautiful and if you like history,
Full of history, super beautiful cathedral. Not take long time to visit, because it is next to city centre. Maybe not the most interesting for little children.

I always take my foreign guest to see this church. It might not be all gold and glory, but it is a wonderful and huuuuge church and a bit piece of Turku's history. Also in December they have the biggest Christmas tree in front the the church!
Definitely worth a visit on your wanderings through Turku -no service was on so we walked straight in. There is no charge to look around.

I like to visit churches and cathedrals when I am travelling although I am not at all into religion. The Turku Cathedral is definitely a place to visit. Impressive about details and size. Don't miss it !

The Turku Cathedral has a special feeling inside. It is high with Gothic interior, but looks quite different on the outside. I has a special atmosphere, because it's sparingly decorated with very little gold and thus does not express wealth and power of its founders. However, it
Turku Cathedral has been in existence for more than 700 years and attending a Christmas oriented festival in it was an out of this world experience>>>so ethereal!
Place to stop by, when visiting Turku. Beautiful area next to river Aura. No need to stay there more than 30mins.

The Turku Cathedral is the most magnificient church in Turku and also in the whole of Finland. Its history is very interesting and the museum there tells of the happenings and persons connected with the history of the church. It has had its central place in Turku for centuries
A huge protestant cathedral. Simplistic, but grand in design. Interesting relics on the sides. Occasionally holds events.

The Turku Cathedral is one of the oldest churches in Finland and gives a great historical insight into the religious history of Finland. However, what I appriciate most is the athmospher when one steps into the church. It is very impressive and beautiful ánd one really feel the
Nice place to visit for some history that stated in the 12 hundreds and a glimpse of nobility in the form of old family tombs and heirlooms
I have seen lots of churces and i got the feeling that this one is half finished with the lack of paintings in the roof and upper walls. Ok place to see.

I lived in Turku for 5 years and have been in and around the church many times. It sits in a beautiful position near the river and opposite the old square of Turku. It is easy to spend an hour or so looking at sections inside the church. If you are lucky you might be there when

The Cathedral of Turku is fantastic! Such high ceiling, such beautiful crypts and paintings. There is a regular organ practice and we were lucky to hear it with my family while we were inside. The high ceiling provides for amazing acoustics. There are numerous Christmas concerts

This cathedral is a landmark in Turku. Easy to reach by car or walking along the river, the cathedral's exterior really doesn't prepare you for the interior. Although the main altar and organ are both stunning, I found the side chapels more enthralling. The side chapel to the
There was an organ practice going on when we got there which added to the experience of this place. It's not ornate like many old churches in Europe but still plenty impressive.

This is a special Cathedral for the Finnish Lutherans. It is not ornate but does contain many interesting historical pieces, crypts and paintings. The high ceilings are to be appreciated for their building achievement.

Building started at 10th century this "dome" is the oldest and most beautiful church in whole Finland. It locates also the seat of archbishop of Finland. With its three ships, handmade decorations and high ceiling it equals with every Medieval church in Europe
This church is one of the landmarks for Turku city, and is beautifully located by the river. There is a nice park around it, and also a café at summer time. Concerts are a must!
A quick visit to this central church close to the river. Nice interior. Had a childrens play area. Worth a visit!
The combination of stonegraves, shields and pulpit was very scandinavien. Beautiful day altar and hardly any visitors.

That's a very traditional old style Scandinavian cathedral. Gorgeous from outside and inside. I would definitely recommend to visit it if you are in Turku. Plus , it's in a very historic part of the city close to University and museums.
Simple Northern Cathedral. I loved the delicate frescos in the archways. No Information in English. still an active church.
Worth a visit but not for lingering: the interior is undistinguished and the museum pretty limited unless you are interested in Ecclesistical history
Definitely beautiful from outside, and fascinating inside. Not very "decorated" but if you sit down when you enter you can smell history.

This is admittedly a nice, large, tall and relatively spectacular building that is worth a look at least from outside. Inside this is rather classical cathedral with all the usual paraphernalia not worth loosing too much time.

Well I guess the Turku Cathedral is something you should see but I was not that special. Quite a plain cathedral although the side chambers with some tombs/coffins were interesting. Some of them has really nice painted glass windows. There is no fee so just pop in to take a look.
The church full of history, handsome architecture and art. Interesting place in so many ways. Alluring history and good acoustics.

The most beautiful part of the church is the altar area and on side aisle one blue-roofed side chapel. Main nave is simple but high vaulted ceiling takes your focus. Beautiful stained-glass windows are abundant and there are a few coats of arms. The altar area as a whole is

Yes the church is one of the landmarks because of its history in Turku. From the outside the building is impressive by its size in a calm area near the river. From the inside it is interesting because of its historic relics and tombs but not by its interieur. So have a look when
Located in the main tourist area. Worth the quick visit to see this church, amazing architecture and history!
Impressive big cathedral on the edge of the river. The size of the building and its position make it a very beautiful place to visit. It is well maintained and the visit is free.
The Turku Cathedral is the national shrine of Finland and is a place worth visiting when at Turku. Admission was free.

This cathedral is impressive in size, age and construction. It really is striking when you approach it. I really found the bare interior stunning and the light quality is really different from other churches from the same time. I bought a coffee and muffin at the cafe close to

I was here for 2 days in Turku and as always I am visiting another Cathedral in another town of the World. It happened that there was a wedding that day and not just one not two but 5 weddings. So locals and tourist are not allowed to enter and wonder around so as not to
The view for the top is great but there is a cost to go up the tower. Not a lot of decoration compared with other cathedrals but it is worth the 5 minute detour.

When I first tried to enter, it seemed like it was locked, but later I saw someone go in, so tried again. The door was really heavy and that was why I had given up the first time. The cathedral is stunning inside - the pulpit, small ship, organ, light - all contribute to a

Turku in itself is a very nice city you can see the history as you drive through it. The Cathedral was amazingly beautiful and the pipe organ was well amazing! They have many historical figures buried their quite interesting.

Located very close to the city centre, the cathedral is truly majestic. It's a truly majestic and historic building. Inside the cathedral, you get the feeling of peace. The entry is free of cost. I would highly recommend this to everyone coming to Turku.

This is one of those few cathedrals where you get that feeling of being at peace upon entering (there were not that many people around and the place was large, which probably contributed to this peaceful feel). The colours, lighting and architecture are just perfect for prayer

It's likely you've seen bigger or grander cathedrals elsewhere, but Turku Cathedral has lots of charm. It's accessible, free, and beautiful inside. There are QR codes for information on different areas of the church. The cathedral is stroller accessible, by the way - the ramp
This is the place to visit in Turku. Extremely impressive church. Easy access. A must when in Turku.
Well worth a stroll along the riverfront to see the Cathedral. Beautiful inside, lots of history. Free to get in. Do a guided tour if you can.
...absolutely gorgeous. Turku Cathedral is huge and beautiful church and especially so for a Finnish church.

While walking around Turku at night we saw the huge Christmas tree outside the Church. Walked inside and it was stunning. A choir was singing with no back up music. The church was all lit up and it was just beautiful. The sound of Christmas Carols in Finnish gave me goose

Thoroughly enjoyed my visit here - the Lutheran Church of Finland built in the mid 13th century. The side chapels have been converted into funeral vaults and you will find places where graves were set into the floor. Stains glass windows are stunning.
It is the oldest cathedral in Finland, back when Turku was the capital city. That should be reason enough to want to know it.

I couldn't look around much because there was some sort of service going on but it was super beautiful inside. The atmosphere is almost ethereal. There were also vendors not to far from the cathedral selling yummy street food, not sure if that's an every day thing or not but if
Worth visiting the cathedral near the river bank and very close to Delhi darbar restaurant. Must go.

Turku Cathedral is a awesome place in Turku, built somewhere in 13th century by the Aura River ...it is one of its first place, around, which finnish habitat grew, In past, as the area was covered with merchants from all land...buying selling goods and services, big ships

We visited for new year and tried to squeeze as many sites into our short stay as possible. The cathedral is beautiful and steeped in history. The other place to visit is the museum. We love Turku and will be re-visiting very soon.
We only saw this from the outside but it was very pretty. It's in a very central location, next to the river, so is easy to see.
The age of the church makes it one of the prettiest churches in Finland. It has an interesting history and I love the architecture of the church. Especially outside it looks very beautiful.
I like the design and architecture of this cathedral. I enjoyed the view both inside and out although we arrived as the sun was going down (December - shorter days).
One of the must see locations in Turku. Along the architecture you can even see the sarcophagus of Karin Månsdotter, Queen of Sweden.

I have always loved churches and this one is as equally beautiful. With coffins of the past rulers and magnificent altar pieces this church works as a museum as well. And in fact there is a museum in the church premises. Recommend!
This is a lovely, very old cathedral in the center of Turku. I stopped in and took a much needed rest inside. It was beautiful, both in and out - well worth a day trip from Helsinki!
Always lovely and so relaxing to walk around in this gorgeous old cathedral. This church is well kept and maintained, even heated in winter time.
It sits by the Aura river. When I was there, there was a Sunday sermon took place. It worths going in and have a look at the interior of cathedral.
Sober but very beautiful scandinavian cathedral. Was there during Christmas ceremony. Warm inside, very much recommended.
The architecture of the Cathedral is really pretty and so is the inside. I was lucky that when I was visiting some kids were doing a Christmas concert, it was breathtaking.
I have been visiting the Cathedral twice during my Erasmus. It was a good one, really huge and majestic; during January 2014 I saw inside a collection of beautiful italian cribs.

Beautiful old church in the heart of Turku. It's a very important piece of Finnish history and considered the most important Finnish monument. Beautiful on the inside. And the organ sent chills down my spine. Have a look! It's worth it!
The church didn't seem much from the outside but I changed my mind when I walked it. Beautiful with nice things to see and music in the background.

Built from 1300. the simplicity of the white stone is broken by frescos, mosaics and side-chapels hosting stone grieves and armors of illustrious people (Finn and Swedes). You can almost "breath" Middle age inside it. I visited it before the closure, so it was a peaceful
The atmoshper is so different from many other churches in Finland and elsewhere as well. WE really enjoid it . !
Easy to pass by and take photos of this beautiful cathedral. Located near the center of town, adjacent to the university. I walked by and took a few photos.
Walking through this beautiful old church is highly recommended -- do try to make one of the short afternoon concerts.

This is a beautiful cathedral that I recommend. I especially enjoyed the life of Christ captured by the paintings around the front of the cathedral. I also liked the fact that it is still being utilized as a house of worship rather than a museum.

This is the major medieval church in Finland and the place to include for a full day visit in Turku. If half a day is the time available I'd prefer Turku Castle. Both buildings are much more impressive inside than outside. The former capital of Finland is worth for a full day

We visited on a Sunday when a congregation was having a service off to the side of the church. It was beautiful hearing the singing soaring up into the high ceilings. You have to look at the floor too.

We liked the grand paved driveway leading to the entrance of the cathedral. We dreamed of loyalty driving up to be crowned and couples in this present day getting married in the cathedral We liked the simplicity and purity of the church sanctuary and to know that the Cathedral

I use to speak with my son about how each church and each monastery is one of God´s houses. The Turku Cathedral is probably His favorite house In Finland. :) This a very impressive place and the energy inside and around it it´s very special. Winter time it´s even better to visit

Turku Cathedral (Åbo domkyrka) is together with Turku Castle (Åbo slott) the symbols of Turku. It's located near River Aura in the city centre. The Cathedral was consecrated in 1300 and dedicated to Virgin Mary and Saint Henry (the first Bishop of Finland). It was originally
Older than expected, this cathedral offers splendid architectural art and houses tombs some of them dated 1622! Worth a visit!

Our short trip to Turku included a short stop at the Turku Cathedral. It is not only imposing but there is a spirit of holiness in the air. As a Hindu visiting this place of God, I was happy to feel it and meditate for a few calming minutes. the Cathedral is not a museum but a
This church is very interesting place to visit. If You are lucky, somebody plays organs! There is many interesting old tombs inside. There is postcards showing the church too.
In the centre of Turku close to the River and the markets is Turku Cathedral. The Lutheran Cathedral is extensive and was very interesting.

A protestant cathedral imposing in its seriousness. Few decorative elements. Field Marshall Mannerheim bestowed the Finnish mothers a fine War Order in 1942, with a very well-worded accompanying text, which hang in the church.

We visited Turku Cathedral on a warm summer day and to our delight someone was practising Sibelius' Finlandia playing the huge church organ - quite an extraordinary feeling! The church is very old and many of the "big" names of Finnish history are buried there. The location of
This cathedral has an impressive outside, very nordic, not exactly the type which invites you to come in. The inside is bright, plain, ideal for clearing your mind or get focused.
It's very beautiful, with an amazing church organ that we were lucky enough to catch being played as a rehearsal for a concert.
Magnificent old church. So much to see and hear, especially if you have a guide with you. Always worth a visit when in Turku.

The church is visible from many parts of the town so its size attracts. Dating back to the 13th century, the exterior is interesting for all the different brick and stone work undertaken over centuries. A sizeable and as a result impressive interior with a number of interesting
Full of history and fabulous stories. Take a guided tour to get the most of this visit. There are beautiful art work, graves and much more.
We went expecting jewel in the crown of Finland and found it gloomy and in a very raw state of build- more like a bunker than a cathedral. Save yourself time and avoid.

Beautiful and breathtaking. You can leave the prayers request at the box by the entrance. There is also service in English and a cosy green space outside. Statues and cyclists. Very romantic too. I am coming back.
Cool church, literally. In hot summer it is cool, in cold winter it is cold cold. Great organs, tainted glasses, surroundings. It has the longest isle in Finlands churches.
Even if you are all "cathedraled out" take a walk and visit this one, Finland's only medieval cathedral. It is beautiful, both inside and out.
I wouldn't drive to Turku just to see this cathedral, but if you are nearby, stop to see it. It is an imposing building and serene inside.

I visited Turku's cathedral many times. Its beautiful place and surrounding area is calm and romantic. There is not much to see inside, but it has very interesting history, so make sure you have a guide with you.

The architecture here is truly magnificant. While I was visiting, they were getting ready for a wedding, so the organist was practicing, which also contributed to the very special atmosphere. Highly recommended!

If you are in Turku on a Tuesday in the summer, make sure to check out the organ concert at the Cathedral. My family and I went to the first concert of the season in early June, and it was absolutely spectacular! Concerts start at 20:00, last about 1 hour, and the cost is free,
Beautiful and fine religious meeting place Nice park arround the catedral. They had fine museum ther and a coxsy cafe

The Turku Cathedral is the town's landmark and therefore hard to miss. It's worth going inside, too! Check out the little sailboats hanging above your head (there is a story behind them)! If you happen to be there in the Advent season, don't miss a nice concert with Swedish

The church looks astoundingly big from the outside. There is a way from the Turku Library (the old building) to the church, and you can see the most picturesque views there. On the inside, the church seems very mysterious. There is also a museum inside the church - entrance
A must-see in Turku. Don't miss the small museum upstairs, for only 2 euros, lots of historic items on display.
For what is the oldest building in Finland, this is an outstanding building in term of its architecture and past history.
One of the magnitude impressive building, entirely in the spirit religiones very simply decorated.Often concerts in the church
More than the cathedral the location is awesomely beautiful. Should not be missed if you go to Turku. Cathedral is also a decent one.
the finest and probably oldest Cathedral in Finland. Very imppresive and big. Free entrance (exept for the museum part which we didn't go)

This is one of the historical landmarks of Finland. Some could say that civilization of Finland started in this area. Well maintained, interesting and historical interior also. Good concerts and also a popular wedding place. Near university area. Peaceful place to visit.
Very nice medival cathedral where the queen of sweden, Karin Månsdotter is buried. She was married to Erik XIV, king of Sweden and she is the only queen who is buried in Finland.

It's huge. When you turn the corner from the Library it's quite impressive how big it is. Maybe this is also the case because the buildings next to it are relatively low. The church is also worth visiting. It's open every day.

Turku is a small town, each main attraction is within walk distance. Turku Cathedral is just across the river. It's tower is imposing and makes you feel small at the moment. It is a beatiful tower, I must say. Inside you will find several crypts of notable nordics, most of them
It's a must see in Turku. It's a very beautiful cathedral. It's a big cathedral that seems to be prepared to the reality of nowdays with bathrooms and places to children play.
Nice historical place. Nice atmosphere. People who like to visit authentic places definitely should visit this Cathedral.

Even you would not consider yourself so religious, Turku Cathedral is a good starting point for 3,5 km walk along the river from Cathedral to Turku Castle. Of course if you want to see all the “seven bridges” the starting point should be further up the river. Around the

Besides the archipelago, the river Aura, Turku castle and the old Turku in Luostarinmäki this is one of the most essentilal sights in Turku. Very important historical and cultural significance in Finlands history.

A magnificent cathedral to visit any time of the year. It is not the most beautiful one (I consider the Church of Mikael in Turku a more beautiful one in style and decoration than the cathedral of Turku) but it is certainly one of the most important monuments in Finland. The

I've seen a lot of cathedrals and basilicas across Europe. They all start to look the same after awhile. The Turku cathedral, with it's Nordic twists of Lutheranism and seafaring history was a pleasant surprise. It's truly a charming little place to wander into (complete with
This something what you are used to see in old European city's, not so expected to see it in Finland. You need to see it it's impressive.
The most important historical monument (as i read in a touristic guide) in Finland! Amazing beauty and historical treasures in it! A MUST visit monument if you travel to Finland!

Finland has grown around this church which is alongside Turku Castle the oldest building. Although the capital of Finland was moved to Helsinki in the 19th century, Turku Cathedral remains in the center of religious life in Finland. The church is absolutely worth a visit
serenity and tranquility. a good place for ones to contemplate also can buy some postcards here :) it's really beautiful in summer, day and night.

When you go inside you are coming to the past - time of kings and queens. You gonna be imprested! If you are interesting in architecture for sure you will descover a lot of foundations from masters of that time.

Great from the outside but nothing really much from the inside, still it stands glorious in the center of the most beautiful square of the city of Turku. It is really impressive and worth a visit. The entrance is free.
One of the lovelier churches in Finland, this one is definitely worth a visit. For more Turku recommendations, see: http://terminalverbosity.com/travel/expatriates/turku-with-children/

The Turku cathedral is a aschetic grand church in the heart of old Turku. Plenty of history and generations of great influential people buried under the floors. Worth a visit when in Turku. It is on the side of the old city center, historic building all around the market place.
Complex, fascinating series of construction phases. Lovely simple interior. Good information available at entry. Free--although donations appreciated.

I love coming to this cathedral now and then. It has a long and interesting history and I love imagining what it looked like hundreds of years ago. Sometimes I enter and sometimes I just walk past it and admire its impressive facade. I'm sure this cathedral won't impress

Main reason to go there was to have a panoramic view of Turku from a vantage point. But was told, the tower is closed to public. A big disappointment it was. The interiors were ok, not as magnificent as from outside. Went to have a look at the museum. Good artifacts and measured

Liked: atmosphere of cathedral, small museum in south gallery. Disliked: a slightly limited range of things in the shop compared with many English cathedrals. A lot of steps at front of cathedral - hard work with suitcase! Could not see a ramp anywhere - perhaps there
It's a very bucolic place. Pretty nice to sit by the river side with friends and drink a beer while chatting.
This was the nicest historical place we saw in Finland. Beautiful, slender gothic features connected with simplicity of Protestant churches, really worth the walk. Recommend to all history lovers!
Turku Cathedral is wonderful and peaceful. Besides of its religious significance the Cathedral is a must see in the city.
This is one of Turku's historic icons and a "must see" if you're there. It's easy to find and it won't take too long to explore it.

I couldn't go inside because the church was closed, so I can judge the church inside, but outside the church is impressive, so solid and with a very nice overall presence and style. In you are in Turku it is worth the visit
