It is a smal little city with some interesting places to view and relax a little . The Cathedral is a old constrution of another past century and it is located in the middle of a square surround of a beatiful and colorful garden and park. Good to have some photos and view a
There is a free organ concert Tuesday evening. We heard an interesting mix of modern and traditional pieces. Worth a visit.

The cathedral in its attractive surroundings, close to parks and the River Aura is is an architectural reminder of Finland's Catholic past and its Lutheran history. The cathedral Museum displays surviving items, remaining after adversities such as the Great Fire of Turku in

This is a beautiful structure and worth a few moments visit. The challenge, especially on a weekend, is getting in between all the wedding parties. It is possibly the most popular wedding venue around.

First of all, my apologies if my opinions are not solid enough. I show them with deep respect. I know the history and importance of this Cathedral for Finland, and you may feel it at every square meter. Many chappels are both sides are more burial chambers than religion

Turku Cathedral is a classic landmark of unexpectedly large size and impressive materials and design. Major photo object in its setting of the river and park and surrounding buildings from earlier years.

Turku cathedral is very nice place near city centre. You can spend here 10 minutes or two hours - depends on your passion for churches :) To be honest for me it is nothing special just "another" big well decorated church but I see no reason why to skip particularly this one. In
is nicely located near by the Aura river. It is a perfect place to feel and see the history of the town.

This Cathedral is the root of the church in Finland so there is alot of history to explore here. In addition its interior is gorgeous, not to the level of mainland Europe Cathedrals but gorgeous non the less. Very close to downtown so just a few minutes walk away from most

Reminds somewhat of those cathedrals that you can find anywhere at Europe but in a more ascetic way. A big arch build church - maybe also some Gothic architecture going on here... If you want to see some kind of history section you will have to pay but a nice place to go and
The acoustics are amazing, you should go and listen to the church choir concert, it's beautiful as is the church itself
A peaceful place with some attractive artefacts. You could visit for five minutes or take longer depending on your interests. A good place for quiet reflection.
just a great space - had the organ guy playing and the acoustics is amazing. It is a 13th century cathedral, just beautiful

Even if you're churched out, this one is worth a visit. Interesting mix of materials and style, with cool personal details. Music events held often: we attended a free organ recital -- roaring Bach, Liszt and Russian angst, on a magnificent monster of a pipe organ.
there is some history to it and a museum that you had love to see ! the art work is quite impressive and the landscape is picturesque ... u ll have good time clicking if a photography enthusiast.

Impressive, next to the river Aurajoki, with a great square in front of the dome and many possibilities to shoot photos from every possible angle. Perhaps not the most elegant church, nor the most extraordinary, but as it is the oldest church in Finland it greatly meets most
we live here - so this is our church. It is medieval and beautiful. There are tombs of earlier kings & queens.

This cathedral is the most historic monument in Finland and well worth a visit. There is not much in ornamentation but it is a pretty church of simple design as befits a 700+ year old building. And, good, clean bathrooms just inside the door.

This is the tallest building in my area, which makes it an easy landmark to find if you get lost. There is a nice park out front and really close to the river. The doors always seem open so it a good place to hide from the cold while waiting for friends. During the holidays

This church is the central biggest landmark of the city. It is hard to be missed because it's giant. I used it to orient myself when I was lost in the city. There is a huge pipe organ inside and I was lucky enough to be there when there was a musician playing. I haven't been
Well yeah.. This is the second big thing. Central place and a silhoutte you can't miss if in Turku. There might be a wedding going on so timetables aren't that accurate.

This church stands in front of a very nice plaza. It is very interesting in that it was built on for many years and endured many changes. The interior is somewhat simple compare to other in Europe, but totally worth checking out.
just an ordinary medieval cathedral. Nothing special. I guess you can find many dozens of cathedrals like this in Europe.

I highly recommend the Turku Cathedral for a visit. Make sure to pay a little more to see the upstairs historical treasures. They have a great English-speaking staff. Check on the hours, they have recently cut back the time.

The cathedral is quite austere from the outside and on first entering that impression is maintain. However, once in the main body of the building there are some surprising and beautiful details to be found. The altarpiece is extremely beautiful as are some of the side chapels

Most important of the few ancient things to see in Turku. The story of the sailing ship suspended inside the church has to be heard. The benches adjacent to Aura river offer a good resting and snacking option.
I found the Turku cathedral an intereresting building, located in a nice place and quiet place. The church organ is a nice one. The frescos on the celling choir are beautiful.

Turku cathedral is situated in the city centre, easily accessible and free of charge (that was a nice surprise). It is a wonderful church. I guess I am somewhat ruined by visiting Great Britain (or Italy) and seeing their cathedrals so it was a bit less impressive. But on a

Situated in the center of Turku by the Aura river this magnificent catedral is one of the main attractions when visiting the former capital of Finland. Many former kings and dignitaries are buried in the chapel inside the catedral.
We went into the cathedral only as we were going past it to the Sibelius museum, none the less it was memorable and atmospheric

Turku is the former capital of Finland. This cathedral is situated in the city center and cannot be missed. It has born witness to many historical events e.g. From the times when Finland was part of Sweden. The construction started late 13th century and the present interior
The oldest and biggest cathedral in Finland. Definitely worth seeing. Also the surroumdings with old Turku is very near.

The place is fine, but nothing very special except of this feeling of big old cathedrals - if you've seen a couple in Scandinavia you will not see anything new. It's for free, but don't treat it as 'must see'.

This was an enjoyable cathedral to visit - I love seeing the magnificent architecture associated with cathedrals throughout Europe. The Turku Cathedral is not terribly ornate, which I found quite refreshing. Overall, we found this to be worth a short visit (~30min); there is a

We arrived at the church just as a concert was beginning, and we didn't have a lot of time on our day trip from Helsinki, so we went for a quick peek inside, listened to a little music, visited the cute little coffee shop, and then walked along the river. So we mostly enjoyed it
Interesting building full of history. The interior is lighter than the exterior suggests. It was slightly out of town so a bit of a walk.

There were lots of signs in English that told about various parts of the cathedral. We did not take a tour or buy a guide, but were able to spend a couple of hours admiring the artwork and design of the building. There is no admission cost to the main part, but there is a
Loads of good history and organ was special. A bit dark but worth a visit and easy to walk from city centre.
Elegant church, well worth exploring and wandering around. Interesting architecture, free to enter. Very calm. Welcoming docents too.

Go in time to get a good place. There are many obstacles that you do not see the altar. The voice come from the microphones. Wonderful place, to image the centuries passed away. Priére a Notre Dame sounded excellent!
Surprisingly busy with coach trips, open until late - ideal for a quick visit and free to enter. Worth crossing the river to get the best views.

I suppose architecture is subject to personal taste but I think it would be hard to be unimpressed by this building. It is an excellent setting by the river, a very tall tower and an amazing vaulted ceiling. Well worth a visit.

You can't miss a visit at this cathedral if you are in Tuku; I was walking in the city centre looking for a restaurant after a business meeting and I stop to have a look. Unfortunately I had not too much time; from outside it is very nice, the cathedral is surrounded by gardens

I loved this cathedral, was impressive. My only criticism was i was sitting peacefully soaking up the atmosphere when a group of tourists came in from a different religion, chatting, shouting and taking pictures, showing no respect for where they were..i suggest that there

The building is quite huge compared to churches that you'll find in Finland. Being use to visit Catholic Churches, it is impressive to compare them with this one who is Protestant. It worth while a few minutes of your time if you are passing by Turku. A nice walk can be done

The whole city of Turku is streaming with life and the cathedral is a great landmark. But once you enter, the whole atmosphere changes. It's a contrast from the outside. It was very quiet to the point of creepiness when i visited. The interiors are not lavished, but contained a

Even though I am not a religious person, Cathedral of Turku is one of the most impressive places I `ve ever visited. You can almost see the bygone centaries in front of your eyes while walking towards the altar. It is a marvellous place to have a visit! :)
We had a short visit on Easter. Very pleasing experience. There is a park outside one could spend time here if the weather is good.
Quite & Calm....sitting arrangements are good...i enjoyed a late night musical show, it was very good

When I enter there it was a dark and an organ is played. I'm orthodox and our temples are different from west church. And I was impressed by it. There are tombes with saints. It's a good place to feel yourself in compare with God and pray to Him.

Turku cathedral is like every tourist story time and time again. After a while, you kinda know how it all works and the special thing is missing. Same goes for me when it comes to churches, cathedrals, etc. Sure its nice and it has its charm, but im already spoiled, so this
The place is definitely worth visiting. It's a symbol of Turku. The museum is interesting. Unfortunately, there weren't any concerts there during our stay in Turku/ Must see!

You can get a lot of information about this medieval cathedral, it's interiors, history and construction, but when visiting, try to find the small details in the church, that should be fun especially when visiting with kids. The first is in the first chapel on the right when you
We liked the interesting alcoves or side chapels with varied styles, especially the Chapel of Lawrence.

One cannot avoid locating the cathedral for it is visible from anywhere along the river promenade. Quarter-hours are pealed by the church bells although maybe the hands of the clock may not exactly correspond to the exact time, but then the building is a lot older than me and I
A very beautiful but not overly ornate cathedral in a lovely part of town. Its right along the water which makes for a nice afternoon stroll after visiting the cathedral.
There is a big organ, so I would recommend to visit some concert in this cathedral. This cathedral contains coffin of Swedish queen. Very beautiful ancient frescos.

Turku Cathedral is impressing since it dates back to the Catholic time in the Nordic. A lot where destroyed in the big fire in 1827 but the buildning is well restored. Do not miss the small museum it is worth the 2 Euro only by the pice of work from Albertus Pictor.

I was impressed with the cathedral and its interior, really big one actually. I was also impressed that it is not that wealthy decorated comparing to the cathedrals I've seen so far. I was also there on the organs concert and it was amazing.
very big cathedral in very historical place ,very closed to the downtown and the public library. the admission is free.
if you got limited time, then this is a must. Here you'll find history in a nutshell, living religion and tranquillity. Skip the museum if you're in a hurry.

The exterior of this church really drew us in and we were lucky enough to visit on a day that someone was playing beautiful organ music inside. The building is structurally amazing and well worth a walk-through.
An interesting building, obviously very old, and with great accoustics - we were fortunate enough to visit while the choir were singing. Some information in English would have been good.

The cathedral is free to enter and the museum very inexpensive. The main cathedral is awe inspiring in it's proportions, more clearly experienced because of the Lutheran austerity. The side chapels are beautiful and the museum offers artifacts from he middle ages on. Loved it!

We visited and a service was coming to a close but they allowed us to quietly come inside. It was very sparse compared to many other cathedral's around the world BUT I really felt that it added to atmosphere, it was typically finnish.

This must be the smallest cathedral I've ever been to! But it's still worth a visit! Central location and easy to find.
nice to see the cathedral we feel the history of the city. Not away from the city centre.I recomend.

The Lutheran cathedral looks impressive situated on a small hill by the Aura river. Quite a few steps to climb to the front entrence? As most churches in Finland the interior is quite plain. I woul have liiked very much to take some pictures from the tower, but it was closed.

Sky high columns predominate the interior of this church. On the right hand side be sure to view the sculpture of the face of Jesus done in frosted acrylic...it looks like it is made of ice.....truly awe inspiring.

The black church steeple dominates the skyline in Turku, so this place just beckons one to go visit it and that is a good thing. The grounds church is on makes for enjoyable walk and the church itself is beautiful with an interesting history.

Impressive considering it is not overly adorned. It's Lutheran, I believe. Services were in session in the side areas which made for a special atmosphere. It was lovely inside and out with the high arches and vaulted ceilings. Very central, overlooking the river and the center

Quite a plain cathedral as they go but as it doesn't cost anything its worth a look. Surprisingly big and imposing when you get next to it and quite nice inside - would have liked to have climbed the tower but it was closed

Impressive inside, and really beautiful from outside. Reconstructed after Turku's Great Fire. Worth a visit, it is one of the main symbols of Turku, and won't take too much time out of your trip. It's next to the river and very close to the city center, so it may be on your way
Well worth a visit. Peaceful and beautiful.A respite from the cold.
Turku Cathedral is definitely worth a visit. It´s huge, massive outside and very impressive also inside.

This is the main building in town, a large church. The interior is beautiful, and ancient with much history to see. Its extremely old in there. It's free to go in, and a few euros to go see more artifacts upstairs. Very cool. Church is open for service on sunday, in Finnish.
One of the most famous churches in Finland. A mark for Turku. Big and beautiful also inside.
Escape the buzzling city and enjoy the peace of the Cathedral. The frequent conserts are wonderful.

The might cathedral of Turku that shows very well the simple style of Finnish churches. With the longest church aisle in the Nordic countries, especially during summer Saturdays weddings are frequent (at best/worst one wedding every 1,5 hours). Concerts given here are beautiful
this Cathedral has a big mixed in-side memories also from the Swedish time in the country.
If you like old churches, this is one of the few in Finland worth to visit.

The most important church in Finland. They began to build this huge dome already in the beginning of 13th century.

Im not a great one for Churches and Cathedrals,but my wife is and we see many on our travels! This one is in a nice location,overlooking the river and city.As with most Scandic Churches,they are not heavily decorated inside,but look ok in a clean Scandic way. Good imformation

We went to Turku to attend Ruisrock but had some time to roam around the city as well. And this cathedral was gorgeous. I haven't visited many old churches so maybe I'm not the best person to say but I really liked this one. But thankfully we were'nt in a hurry because first

text.wiki:
Kupittaa (Swedish: Kuppis) is a district in Turku, Finland. It is located on the eastern side of the city's centre, around the Kupittaa Park, the first landscaped park in a Finnish city. The district serves as a centre for recreation and business. Turku has recently planned a residential area for 750 residents on the premises of a former HKScan sausage factory.The area hosts, among other things, numerous sports facilities, such as the Veritas Stadion, a Finnish baseball stadium, a velodrome, a bowling alley, a skateboarding area and a BMX track, and the Kupittaa open-air swimming pools. The ice hockey arena in the district was demolished in 2005. A new one was inaugurated in November 2006.
Most of the Turku Science Park business centre is located in Kupittaa. The centre is currently expanding around Kupittaa railway station, next to Finnish national road 1 (part of European route E18) between Helsinki and Turku. 
According to a version of the legend, the first pagan Finns were baptised into Christianity by the Bishop Henry at a spring in Kupittaa Park on Midsummer Day in the year 1155. In the 18th century, the spring was used as a spa facility.


== Name ==
The name Kupittaa may be associated with an old border and may be related to the word kupitsa a name for a boundary mark. Another theory is that it comes from the Russian word for a merchant, kupets.


== See also ==
Turku Science Park


== References ==


== External links ==
 Media related to Kupittaa at Wikimedia Commons

text.wiki:
Forum Marinum is maritime museum located in Turku, Finland.


== History ==
The museum was founded in 1999 by merging of Turku maritime museum established in 1977 and Åbo Akademi University museum of maritime history established in 1936.
Lonely Planet Scandinavia describes it as "an impressive maritime museum," and notes that it is near Turku Castle.


== Exhibitions ==
The main exhibition was renewed in 2016 and it is now called Work at Sea. Other permanent exhibitions include:
The Five Lives of our National Treasure (The history of the Suomen Joutsen from 1902 to 2009)
The Forum Marinum exhibition on board the Bore (History of the Bore from construction to the present day)
At the Shipyard (History of the Finnish Shipbuilding)
At the Engine Factory (History of the Ship Engine Manufacturing in Turku)


== Museum ships ==
Full rigged ship Suomen Joutsen
Barque Sigyn
Bermuda ketch Daphne
Steam tugboat Vetäjä V
Turunmaa-class gunboat Karjala
Minelayer Keihässalmi
Von Fersen-class transport vessel Wilhelm Carpelan
Nuoli-class fast gunboat Nuoli 8
Taisto-class motor torpedo boat Tyrsky (Taisto 3)
MS Bore, a former steam-powered cruise ship currently used as a floating hostel
Coast patrol boat RV 214 (Rautaville)
Police boat PMV-1391
Pilot cutter MKL 2103


== References ==


== External links ==
Official website
text.quote: Historic tall ships & Finnish naval vessels on display in maritime & naval museums in a shipyard.
trip: We were a bit on a rush on that day so didn't manage to check out all the boats and the inside museum. Easily reachable by bus or the city bike. It is a bit far to walk from the city center. They have a nice selection boats/ships here. Very nice to visit on a sunny summer day

We finally visited this maritime museum on a rainy day. Tickets 10 € pp. The main exhibitions walk you through Finnish Naval History, maritime shipping, professional fishing, cruise shipping industry etc. all from the individual’s “working at sea” point of view. In the
If you like ships, industry and things related to war this is the place to be. Huge place with alot to see.

Located about 10 minutes from cruise ship terminals by Aura river. Good selection of old tools, shipyard photoes, scaled models, motors and mainly small historical boats. Has good naval and maritime rescue history areas. Popular lunch restaurant and cafe next to main entrance.

The museum was boring for us who are not interested in maritime matters, mostly just pictures, some ships and engines etc., we went through within 10-15 minutes... The ship MS Bore outside on the river was also not interesting, not much to see either. Visiting the ship Suomen

Here you can walk for a couple of miles to feel the maritime history and atmosphere of Turku. While walking we learned about the old lighting wooden beacons in use since the 1220s! And of course we took photos with the monumental sculptures such as the giant chamomile flower.

Even if maritime history isn't your top area of interest, Forum Marinum has so much about history of Finland, the Baltic sea, seafaring, ships and vessels, that you will surely find something interesting. There are also hands on activities for kids. The museum is in two

This is a must place to visit when in Turku. Located on the banks of the Aura river, this museum gives you a perfect overview of the development of the Finnish marine life. Excellent descriptions of each display and era give you more "meat on the bones" with some sound

The museum is not so interesting and the value for the money is not great. I would only recommend the sailing ship that was used to train the sailors. War ship is interesting to compare with the sailing ship. Very narrow corridors, small spaces, bit claustrophobic...

Great place to wait for the ferry to Stockholm or Helsinki ; it’s easy walking to the terminal. The maritime collection is interesting and there is a lot of information in English. The restaurant was a real surprise; good food, buffet style at lunch. Friendly staff. Good value

I loved this place. The ships are interesting and if you love the sea and exploring it then this museum is for you. I wish that we could have visited the other ships but it was winter so we were only allowed to visit the bore.
Propably the most interesting place to visit during the winter time in Turku. The variety of exhibitions will come across most demanding visitors. Worth seeing with children.

Put on your warmest clothes and enjoy walking along the canal. Lovely monuments and pieces of art. Marine museums. You can end up with visiting the famous Turku castle or go direct to the Silja Line terminal.

Really interesting areas with so much history coupled with a totally different feel. Something started here and the people of Turku are proud and are showing their excellence as they attempt to take a massive step to bring the world to this interesting City with so much
Its big and provide a lot of information and quality of expositions is very high. Pls mind there are two sections of the museum in two separate buildings. Both worth to visit
Extensive museum with full size and model boats, special exhibitions and an inventive shop. Some of the boats were closed because it was off season, but there was still plenty to see.

We visited with colleagues on a sunny Sunday afternoon. There is plenty to see, spread over two buildings, with exhibits covering a wide of maritime topics. We found it very interesting and would come back again as we probably didn’t see everything on offer. There is a nice

In this museum next to Turku Castle, you can explore the Finnish maritime and naval history. The museum has a big collection of vessels and museum ships. For example, you can visit the sailing ship Suomen Joutsen, the warship Karjala and the museum ship Bore.
very interesting visit for mariners. some very old items at a nice exhibition. very sorry to hear that part of the boats were closed for the season although it was august.

This is a great museum for kids and adults alike. Plenty of visual interest is provided by the many large and model boats on display, and for the avid readers there is also plenty of detail. You can learn all about the history of seafaring, shipbuilding, fishing and naval

Here one could use a guided tour through all those nice prepared and described ships. Often the description in english is missing and explanation is needed to understand context and use of all the devices on board of those ships. It is nice to see anyway! After all, it takes a

The museum is located near the castle of Turku and harbour. It is very easy to access. The exhibition is devided in two different buildings, the first building houses an exhibition of Finnish marine engineering and it’s history and the other displays the history of Finnish Navy.
This is a great place to take those that love boats. If you just want to view them from the outside they are great to look at if maritime isn’t your thing.

This ship is well worth visiting ... but be prepared it takes ages to view well! There’s so much to see and read I especially liked the details of the trade exhibitions ... who’d have thought anywhere would export lichen (primary food for reindeer) as a remedy for tuberculosis!

Maritime museum by the river Aura. A few historic ships too. Children (boys) aged 6-16 were quite excited. Not just technology but stories and history too. Nice area with cafes and restaurants not faraway from market square.
Well-equipped and constructed exhibition set. Interesting stories...Very nice location by the riverside, nice restaurant nearby...
Historic sailships and old finnish navy warships in river Aura. More smaller vessels in the yard. Lot of items in indoors collection and interesting exhibitions. Definately a place to visit in Turku.

We visited the museum and the gift shop. So many things to see. Be prepare to spent there more then 1 hour if you want to discover everything at least a bit in detail. There is an opption to visit also one ship outside in the harbour for additional fee - I recommend it as well.
I suggest to visit this martime museum. Even ships inside and large exhibition of Finnish martime history. I found this very interesting place.

Wonderful sea and maritime exhibition in real harbor environment. There are vessels from a 19th century's sail ship to almost modern patrol boats - more than 100 vessels. It's possible to visit on board of the biggest ships, for example fregate "Suomen Joutsen" (s/y "Swan of

I attended an event at the Forum Marinum, had a lunch and visited the museum and the gift shop in this activity center. The ships in the museum are open only during the summer time. Very well functioning area overall.

A beautiful maritime museum that displays Finnish maritime, naval and shipbuilding history. The museum has great conference venues and a good lunch restaurant. Any visit will take 2-3 hours at least if you're not planning on a run-through. Remember to visit the museum ships at

Thoroughly enjoyed a recent evening visit here as part of a business trip to Turku. Exhibits are numerous, varied and very interesting for those with an interest in ships and ship building. Evening dinner at the museum was very good, both the food and the service.

Turku has centuries long history with maritime industries, including ship building. And the ships built in Turku range from small crafts to ocean going cruise ships, which are more like ocean going cities. Forum Marinum details Turku's marine history quite well. It also has an
Really informative and well set out museum. Really pleased we opted to include the ships/boats as part of our visit. Good value for money.

Forum Marinum offers something for everyone: there are exhibitions, both permanent and changing - and several museum ships to visit, including the famous Suomen Joutsen and the unique barque Sigyn. For kids there's a lot to do and experience on the ships as well as in the
This museum combines museums exhibits in two buildings with three museum ships you can visit. An excellent way to explore Finnish maritime history in its various facets.
A good maritim museum.very much to see even to people who are not so intrested in motors etc. Very nice guides, kind and helpful! Several big boats to visit, and even a nice cafeteria/lunch.

This is by far the best maritime museum we've visited. The ship models are amazing, the videos and other materials informative and entertaining, and the boat tours are unique. Besides, where else have you seen a three-story room filled with outboard motors?

Due to limited amount of time we only visited the ships outside - the frigate "Suomen Joutsen" (Swan of Finland) and the two minelayers. They are well preserved and worth visiting, takes some time though to catch the details. I'm sure the museum itself would have been also worth

Forum Marinum has plenty to offer. In the summertime you can visit the ships and also visit the museum telling a story about Turku maritime history. This all takes time, but you can have a drink or eat at the Göran restaurant.( Also Turku Castle has a lunch café just around the

For the 9euros(10) if you want to add the Bore experience to your day,which I highly recommend This is a very well laid out and displayed museum Telling the story of Finland's and Turku marine history Lots of detail in a clear and easy to read/understand way I liked the gangway
full of interesting maritime ships aged and well preserved includung a hydrocar which can run in water and ice and land

text.wiki:
Posankka is a statue located in Turku, Finland. The statue, which is located near the campus area of the University of Turku and the Turku Student Village, represents a hybrid between a marzipan pig ("possu") and a rubber duck ("ankka"). It is a pink animal with a duck's lower body and a pig's head.The statue was designed by Alvar Gullichsen in 1999 when it was placed floating in the Aurajoki river in Turku. The statue has stood at its current location since 2001.Every winter, a Santa Claus hat is put on Posankka's head,  and on Walpurgis Night it is capped with a Finnish student cap.


== References ==


== Further reading ==
Leslie Mullen (August 2008). "Pondering PigDuck". Astrobiology Magazine European Edition.
"Pinkki sekasikiö ui sydämiin". Turun Sanomat (in Finnish). May 15, 2009. (history of Posankka with some pictures)

text.wiki:
The Qwensel House is the oldest wooden house in Turku, Finland. It is bourgeois housing from the autarchic times that has survived in its entirety. The house was built approximately in the year 1700 in an area that was reserved for the nobility in the city plan made up by Peter Brahe in 1652. Today, the Qwensel House operates as the Turku Pharmacy Museum and café.


== Pharmacy Museum ==
The shop wing of the building was furnished with a pharmacy in the 19th century. The pharmacy has a material room and a herb room, two laboratories and an office. The office has the oldest survived pharmacy interior in Finland.
The exhibition wing of the building has Åke Lydman's collection of pharmacy utensils on display. There is also a pharmaceutical research laboratory and pharmacy history exhibition in the wing. In addition to the main exhibitions, there are also varying smaller exhibitions and programmes held at the museum every year.
The use of pharmaceutical herbs can be studied with the lead of an "apothecary" at the Children's Pharmacy, the courtyard and outdoors. The authentic pharmacy cabinet is from the Uusikaarlepyy Pharmacy.
The former stable, toilet and barn are located at the northern end of the Pakaritupa wing of the building. The Pipping family used to have a garden with apple trees and plants along Linnankatu (formerly Kuningattarenkatu).


== References ==


== External links ==

text.wiki:
Wäinö Valdemar Aaltonen (8 March 1894 – 30 May 1966) was a Finnish artist and sculptor. The Chambers Biographical Dictionary describes him as "one of the leading Finnish sculptors".He was born to a tailor in the village of Karinainen, Finland. He became interested in art after being deaf as a child, and attended the School of Drawing of the Turku Art Association from age 16, or specifically between 1910 and 1915. He had spent many of the early years at this school studying painting, but he was mainly self-taught as a sculptor. He learned the technics of treatment of marble with his relative Aarre Aaltonen, and by working as a trainee stonemason in Hirvensalo. Sculptor Felix Nylund was a substitute teacher in the art school in Turku for one season, and his work was inspiration for young Aaltonen.A journey Aaltonen made to Italy in 1923 opened his eyes to cubist and futurist art. These elements can primarily be seen in his paintings.
As the Republic of Finland arose, and the First World War raged, he sculpted War Memorials. He soon became a nationalist icon, the exemplar Finn, establishing an exhibition in Stockholm in 1927. His sculpture is nationalist in nature, and he is noted for monumental figures and busts portraying citizens of Finland. An example is the 1925 sculpture of Paavo Nurmi, a cast of which is exhibited outside the Helsinki stadium. Another notable work is that of Jean Sibelius, a bust of 1928. These two works, like the main body of his work, are bronze casts—though he did work in stone and even glass. Though chiefly naturalistic, the cubist influence is also present here. He was one of the early 20th-century pioneers of direct carving.
When the new House of Parliament for Finland was built, architect Johan Sigfrid Sirén wished he could buy sculptures directly from Aaltonen. Instead, an open competition was announced, and Aaltonen's Work and the Future was selected as the winner. The series of gilded plaster sculptures that Aaltonen completed in 1932 were cast in bronze after his death.Aaltonen was married four times. His first wife was singer Aino Alisa Pietikäinen from 1920, second wife actor Elsa Emilia Rantalainen from 1931, third wife gallerist in Galerie Artek Elvi Elisabet Hernell from 1942 and fourth wife medical doctor Marie Elisabeth Maasik from year 1961. His son Matti Aaltonen became an architect, who designed e.g. Wäinö Aaltonen museum in Turku.A large collection of his works are on permanent exhibition at the Wäinö Aaltonen Museum of Art in Turku. His work was also part of the sculpture event in the art competition at the 1948 Summer Olympics.


== Works ==

Tytön pää, n. 1917
Graniittipoika, 1917–1920
Maria Jotuni, 1918–1920

Statues on Hämeensilta bridge, Tampere:  Eränkävijä (the Hunter), Veronkantaja (the Tax Collector), Kauppias (the Merchant) ja Suomen neito (the Maiden of Finland), 1927–1929
Myrsky (Memorial statue for the 53 victims of the sunken Finnish torpedo boat S2 in Reposaari, Pori), 1930
Statues in the plenary chamber of Parliament House 1930–1932

Memorial of the Battle of Kämärä, 1939/1949

Lahden sankaripatsas, 1952
Rautatienrakentajien muistomerkki, 1957, Hyvinkää

Statues of president sin front of Parliament house: K. J. Ståhlberg, 1957–1958 ; P. E. Svinhufvud, 1957–1959
Genius Montanus (on Aaltonen's grave in Turku), 1960

text.wiki:
Michael's Church (Finnish: Mikaelinkirkko, Swedish: Mikaelskyrkan) is a church situated in central Turku. It is named after Archangel Michael and was finished in 1905. It dominates the western skyline of the city of Turku was designed by Professor Lars Sonck and is one of the most popular wedding churches in Turku being able to seat 1,800 people. When Sonck won the competition for the church in 1894, he was only a 23-year-old architectural student. Michael's Church is older than Michael's parish. The parish only dates back to 1921.


== Architecture ==
Michael's church is a distinguished example of the neogothic style in architecture. It is a long church with three aisles, galleries and a multifaceted choir. In addition to the main entrance there are also doors at each corner of the church. The sacristy is situated behind the choir. The main spire rises to a height of 77 meters from the foundations.
The main building material of the walls of the church is red brick. The roof is made of grey green slate from Norway. However, the majority of the material used in the construction of the church are native materials from Finland. For the foundations, the stone steps, and the walls, natural stone was quarried not far from Turku.
Even before the construction work started, Sonck wanted to make considerable changes to his winning design, but the church council did not agree to the proposed changes and in the end only minor detail changes were made to the facade. As for the interior, however, Sonck got a much freer hand to make changes from his original drawings. This is clearly seen in the deviations from the style of the times: Jugend follows Gothic and Romantic Nationalism.


== Interior design ==

Max Frelander the architect, who worked as an assistant to Sonck, has contributed to the interior design. A rich Jugend ornamentation decorates both the interior, the staircases and the windows. The altar, the pulpit, the altar rail, and the window frame are all made of Finnish soapstone. The central motif of the altar is a cross, on which base there is a symmetrical carving of two serpents. Also on the corner level of the altar rail there are rings of twisting serpents. The top of the cross is ornamented with a dove, the symbol of the Holy Spirit. The Jugend windows of the choir, which depict Finnish pine, were destroyed in a bombing raid during the Finnish Winter War (1939–1940). The national romantic movement is particularly dominant in the design of the choir. Motifs from Finnish nature are associated with traditional Christian symbolism.
The original window paintings, which were destroyed during the Winter War, were by the artist Willy Baer. The new ones were obtained in 1953. These were designed and done by the artists Hilkka Toivola and Otso Karpakka. The principal subjects of these works of art that were made in the Paris glass painting studio of Jean and Pierre Gaudin, are "the Good Shepherd" and "Faith, Hope, and Charity". Along with the new windows the stylistic unity of the interior of the church disappeared. Consequently, in the 1950s other changes were made in the interior design of the church to match the Gothic exterior. First the decorative paintings of the choir and the arch of triumph were painted over, and later the wall paintings in the body of the church and the staircases. However, the original decorative pictures were restored in connection with the general repair work on the church that was carried out in 1964-65.
Michael's Church underwent a thorough renovation in the 1980s. First, an exterior repair work was carried out in 1984-85. The decayed exterior brick work and the roof were completely rebuilt. Reconditioning of the interior was done in 1985-87. First the sacristy of the church was returned to its original condition. After this came the main body of the church and the staircase. The ceiling and the interior wall surfaces were carefully cleaned of grime of decades. The decorative designs were repaired and returned to their original paint finish or painted afresh. Floors were resurfaced with a new limestone finish. The acoustics of the church, which had proved a problem, was improved. In connection with this renovation work, a basic restoration of the 48 rank mechanical organ made in Kangasala in 1965 was also done. In 2002 the new organ with 52 ranks and 3633 pipes was built by the Swedish organ builders Grönlunds Orgelbyggeri AB.
The church bells have rung out from the main spire since 1931, and they were a gift from Edla and Hjalmar Aarnio. Reino Lehto made a gift to the church of the model ship hanging from the gallery. Kaarina Lehmussaari, lecturer in textiles, donated a new decorated altar cloth.

text.wiki:
The Old Great Square (Finnish: Vanha Suurtori, Swedish: Gamla Stortorget) is a medieval market square located in the city centre of Turku, Finland. It is located in the II District in very close proximity to Turku Cathedral. The area was the administrative and commercial centre of Turku since the founding of the city in the 13th century up until the Great Fire of Turku.
Today, there are buildings alongside the Old Great Square, but only on the southern side because the blocks on the northern side changed to Porthaninpuisto after the fire. There are four historical buildings which the City of Turku restored for cultural use: the Brinkkala Mansion, Old Town Hall, Hjelt Mansion and Juselius Mansion. The buildings were mainly constructed after the fire and represent neoclassicism.


== Historical buildings ==


=== Brinkkala Mansion ===
The Brinkala Mansion is best known for the traditional proclamation of Christmas Peace, which has been given from the Brinkkala Mansion balcony each Christmas Eve at 12:00 since 1886. Prior to that, Christmas peace was proclaimed from the "doors and windows of the town hall" as the old saying went. The wooden balcony known as the Christmas peace balcony was added to the Brinkkala facade during renovations from 1884 to 1886. The declaration started in the 14th century. The earliest information about the Brinkkala Mansion is from the 16th century when it was a town house of the owner of Brinkhall Manor in Kakskerta. Before its renovations from 1884 to 1886, it was a hotel, town hall and Turku police station. Nowadays, it is a space for art galleries and banquet halls. There is a coffee house located in the courtyard. The Turku Medieval Market also takes place in the courtyard.


=== Old Town Hall ===
It is assumed that the City of Turku administrative centre was headquartered at the Old Town Hall since the 14th century. The most famous of the Turku town halls was the stone building planned by master bricklayer Samuel Berner, finished in 1736. Berner's town hall was destroyed by the fire of 1827, along with its bell tower. A private house was built upon the walls of the badly destroyed building, this house being acquired by factory owner Juselius in the 1850s. The building was redone into a three story factory in 1899, which was active until the 1920s. In 1932, the building was acquired by the City of Turku, and was for police department use. Nowadays, it is a space for galleries and a banquet hall and concerts.


=== Hjelt Mansion ===
After the fire, Captain Hjelt bought the site along the town square, and built the impressive two story stone building in 1830. The Hjelt Mansion is the only remaining stone building in Finland which clearly represents the St. Petersburg empire style. The Hjelt Mansion was taken over by the City of Turku in the 1930s, at which time both stories were used by the police department. After this, the downstairs level was a used as the children's and young adult's section of Turku City Library, and the Turku Cultural Centre worked in the upstairs level. The library section moved to the new building of Turku Main Library and the Turku Cultural Centre moved next door to the Old Town Hall.
Four Baltic sea organisations moved into the building at the beginning of 2008: UBC Environment and Sustainable Development Secretariat, WHO Healthy Cities, Centrum Balticum and Valonia. The building was officially designated as the Itämeritalo ("Baltic Sea house") on 19 August 2008.


=== Juselius Manor ===

The new renaissance Juselius Mansion is the newest of the buildings in the area. It was built by Carl Fredrik Juselius in 1892, originally as his home. It has been a residential building for city officials, space for the police department and a dociros office. Nowadays, the building is used for other purposes, such as the legendary restaurant Teini.


=== Katedralskolan i Åbo ===
Katedralskolan i Åbo is a Swedish-language senior high school, built after the fire on the foundation of the former Hovrätt by C.L. Engel. Its style is empire. There reportedly was a school under the authority of Turku Cathedral in the Turku city centre in late 13th century called Turun katedraalikoulu.


== Events ==
There are different events organised at the Old Great Square throughout the year. Turku Medieval Market is organised in June and July, stretching out to Porthaninpuisto, the courtyard and Luostarin Välikatu. Christmas City events also take place for three weekends  as well as events for Turku Night of the Arts.


== Prospects ==
The Old Great Square and its historical surroundings have been designed to be marketed as the old part of the city of Turku. Under EU protection, the idea is to revive the area to a European style by attracting more cafes and restaurants and organising different events at the square and park. Furthermore, a bridge called Pennisilta, to replace the one destroyed by the fire, is due to be built to connect the old part of the city to the traffic centre.

trip: A good place for a quiet break. Often small scale art exhibitions, always great glass art and light.

Chapel is short distance from Turku and well worth a visit. The outside is not memorable.Sort of looks like an upside down partially open clam shell with a metal roof. The interior is striking. It is entirely constructed of pine wood. Truly spectacular pine walls that follow the

I saw some photos from the place. It looked interesting. It is rather far away from the city center so I recommend using a car. There is some public transportation also available. Yet it is just another chapel. Yes it looks nice. Yes it's peaceful in there. Yes there is art

I saw this chapel in the Phaidon Helsinki guide, so we went there. It was amazing. I didn't expect to see such a specially designed chapel. From the outside, you see it's a ship upside down, but the inside is even more impressive because, although you see it's really narrow, you

The chapel is a beautiful building inside and out. It is a little out the way, but if you are visiting the Hirvensalo island, or this corner of the Turku archipelago, be sure to pay the chapel a visit.

Innovative architecture. Due to this and to the materials, the idea of the chapel is the union with nature. On specified days, a prayer worship is organised. Although it was only in Finnish (which we don't speak) when we attended, we enjoyed the piano music.

A must visit. Exquisite wooden church.

text.quote: Museum with a collection of instruments, sheet music & recordings, plus a seasonal concert series.
trip: Really interesting museum, I can recommend it for everyone who are interested in music and Jean Sibelius. During fall and spring they even organise live concerts! And the exhibition 2020 about architect Erik Adlercreutz was really nice!
The museum was quiet the day we attended. The instrument displays were first class. The concert area looked tremendous. Worth a visit and easy to find.

This museum is split in two - the amazing displays of musical instruments from Early Music times to today and a couple of rooms given over to the life and work of Jean Sibelius. There are the musical instruments you would expect and others which are weird and wonderful. The

Although the name is Sibelius Museum, it is a music museum. There is also much more to see. However, Sibelius plays a big part. The museum building itself with its stunning Chambre Music Hall is also worth to see.

The museum features not only the life and works of Sibelius, but also has a nice collection of different musical instruments from all over the world. I also enjoyed reading the trivia about Sibelius the composer. Very friendly staff. A nice hour spent here.

As a classical music lover, I was very at home here! There is a small display of musical instruments, including a harpsichord you can try playing, and a small exhibition about Sibelius' bohemian lifestyle interwoven with excerpts of music he composed at the time. In the centre

Spent about 1 hour there before we left Turku. Really worth the time to visit. There are not only exhibition about Sibelius, but also many rare instruments and photos of the past. I like and enjoyed the museum.

Relatively small, text in English, Finnish and Swedish. Even if you read absolutely everything, you are done in max 90 min. Interesting instruments display and Sibelius life, conductor section nothing worth seeing. No cafe or food, meagre choice of gifts in a giftshop. Entrance

I am an unashamed Sibelius lover, so had to go to this museum! A modern, stark building from the outside but is inviting and well laid out on the inside. The staff kindly played my favourite Sibelius music while I looked over some fascinating manuscripts, photos and displays of

I hate the building, it's ugly and unfriendly - but, a bit like the Tardis, don't be put off by the Interior! Currently there's an exhibition on 100 years of .Finnish composers - and it's fascinating. Do take a look if you are in town and near the cathedral! Good toilets.

I travelled on a VOYAGES JULES VERNE tour, where I was left in Turku for an extra two days. Upon arrival at this museum, the ticket clerk made me feel very welcome. As a Sibelius enthusiast, I asked for the Karelia suite and sat alone in the lavish auditorium to listen to the
The museum is located in a beautiful moden building. There is collection of music instruments and a presentation of Sibelius life. Nice way to discover this famous Finish composer.

Licated just behind the cathedral, it us a concrete building most likely from the 70s. It is a wuirt place, dedicated to the eminent composer and hosting temporary exhibits like just now "conducting in Finland"

The museum is certainly interesting for those into classical music and Sibelius, though in all honesty the display is rather outdated and could do with modernisation. That said, the building itself is incredibly beautiful and everything from materials to furniture and display

A beautiful building offering a fascinating collection of musical instruments together with a rich and absorbing history of Sibelius' life and music. When not being used for concerts, the auditorium is used to play his music providing a musical backdrop to your visit. Really

Not being particularly interested by the history of music I did not expect much from this museum however the visit was surprisingly pleasant. The museum is split in 2 parts, the first exposing a collection of (mostly ancient) instruments. It is very well done and informative and

The central location of the museum next to the cathedral is worth taking advantage of if you are in any way interested of the work of Finland’s national composer Jean Sibelius (1865-1957) who was born in Hämeenlinna and died in Järvenpää and got part of his inspriration from

This gem of a museum offers a quiet space to listen to Sibelius' music, learn more about his life, times and the development of musical instruments. I loved the elegant, grained concrete arcs framing the small open hall where concerts are sometimes held. We visited this museum
A great little museum. There are occasional concerts in the evening. There was a lovely recording of Sibelius being played in the small concert hall which was open in the centre of the museum

We admired this fantastic place, designed by Woldemar Baeckman. It is one of the most original building of the 1960s in Finland. The Sibeliusmuseum has very well organized collection that connects life and music .

Loved the exhibit ! I had really had no idea of what to expect. The exhibit explained not just different instruments, but the chance also to play a harpsichord. Wonderful music played in the background. Head/Earphones were available to listen to even more music/compositions.
It was a pleasure to fwalk thru the live of Finland most famous composer. We were impressed by the numbrr of works that he had finished

I went there for an exhibition and I quite liked it. It is relatively small, but interesting. Sibelius and his music just belongs to Finland! They organize concerts in there regularly during the year (cheaper for students) - check out their homepage for more infos!
Part of Turku pass, one of the reasons we like Turku so much. Concert was free, interesting, somewhat intense as Finns are very serious about their music.

This is a museum containing mostly musical instruments from around the time of Sibelius and before (one of which was a very usual combination of keyboard and bowed string). The collection was established by the local university, Sibelius also has some early connections with
Small, interesting and well located Museum next to the restaurant Hus Lindman, by the river, near the university area and Cathedral. Selection of musical instruments and well designed building.
If you like classical music or Sibelius, go there. they also have a small and cheap gift shop. They plas beautiful classical music all the time.
Liked: films of Sibelius, some weird and wonderful instruments. Extracts of his music to listen to. Disliked: I had hoped that the shop might sell sheet music.

The outside does look rather like an air raid shelter! Pleasant on the inside with interesting displays of historic instruments and about Sibelius. Listening to Finlandia in the central auditorium seemed very appropriate and quite an emotional experience - I'd like to check out
If you like classical music and are interested the history of music instruments manufacturing it's absolutely worth it the visit! Especially the actual exhibition in the basement is fascinating.

A very interesting museum. Takes about an hour to look round. There are lots of instruments on display which are interesting as works of art as well as their musical quality. There is an auditorium where you can sit and listen to some of Jean Sibelius' music. Worth a visit.

This museum contains many clearly displayed exhibits, with supporting written remarks in Finnish and English. Some old films can be viewed, although the commentary is in Finnish, the snippets of music are a delight. Also some audio visual equipment. We also went to a concert in

This is a small museum but with a lot to see. I believe that there are about 1400 instrument from various countries. All the instruments are well displayed and the space in the museum makes it pleasant to walk around. The section on Sibelius is interesting and well done. Don't

This is a small museum which doesn't cost much to enter. And it is a delight for music-lovers, much more than those wishing to learn more about Sibelius, the man. The exhibition on Sibelius is found in a small tiny room. But the rest of the exhibition on musical instruments
It's a great museum where you can see almost all musical instruments and listen to great music. Very interesting! It's definitely worth visiting. It's a must, I should say.
Yeah, it was just okay to walk around and see many different old instruments. However the concert I saw there was very nice.
google: Fascinating museum if you are interested in music and old instruments. Right now they have an exhibition about the architect Erik Adlercreutz, for those interested in that. During fall and spring they have live concerts every Wednesday!
Nice museum but not the biggest. Very informative about Sibelius
The very specific museum in Finland with live classic music concerts and events
Lovely architecture, good acoustics
A beautiful collection of many instruments and their historical information, staff was very friendly. Worth a visit if you're into music history.
Interesting museum! Don't miss the Sibellius exhibition!
Interesting collection of instruments

Excellent collection of instruments (at least to me, as an amateur). Nice, concise descriptions and background information next to each case. The staff was very friendly, they offered to play Sibelius' music in the background during our visit. Worth paying a visit wild in Turku.

The main hall has some interesting instruments like a combination cello-piano and a harpsichord you can play yourself, plus an interactive display of how harpsichord, clavier and piano mechanisms work. But the best part is the smaller hall …
Interesting if you're into music.
Interesting place to visit
